QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask: is the Prime Minister arguing that because he questions the political motives in the establishment of the royal commission in Western Australia he is now entitled to disregard its findings? Is that not an attack on the integrity of the royal commissioner and the many witnesses who contradict the Lawrence version of events? Aren't the Australian people entitled to expect that they not be lied to by a minister? If the evidence demonstrates that she lied, aren't they entitled to expect the Prime Minister to act on that finding rather than defame the commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the most reasonable thing to do in this whole unreasonable business is to wait and see what the findings of the royal commission actually are before making any judgment at all about what the response will be by the government or by anyone else. It is the case that we regard this royal commission as wholly inappropriately established, for the wrong purpose at the wrong time, by a government which ought to be absolutely ashamed of itself for using the forms and practices of royal commissions to embark upon an escapade which simply has no precedent in anyone's memory in any jurisdiction—an exercise involving the investigation neither of criminality nor financial impropriety, nor abuse of power, nor a national security issue, nor a policy issue, nor anything of a kind which has traditionally been the subject of a royal commission. So it is a political exercise, it is not a proper royal commission exercise, and it should be judged by the kinds of standards that are applied when we are evaluating allegedly political offences. And that is all I say, and that is all anyone in the government has said, about the royal commission.

PARA.TAB: We are not going to respond to hypothetical questions about what we may be prepared to do and when. Let the course of events unfold and, in particular, let Dr Lawrence speak for herself before that inquiry, before rushing to judgment and before making assumptions. It is outrageous that she should have been targeted for this assault by this West Australian government in this way. To the extent that the question in issue is the accuracy of different recollections three years after the events, there is every reason, we repeat, why Dr Lawrence should be believed, notwithstanding how many other people might purport to have different recollections. She should be believed on the basis of her own clearly stated recollections just a few days after the events in question, and she should certainly be given the benefit of any reasonable doubt in this respect.

It is not a matter, you see, of assuming that someone in this whole affair has to be lying—either Dr Lawrence on the one hand or those who have taken a different view of events on the other hand. People can simply make mistakes in their recollection of these events, and this is a point that was of course acknowledged very, very frankly by none other than your leader, Mr Howard. He was asked, you see, how it was that Alexander Downer could possibly have got himself into a situation of directly contradicting what the Vietnamese ambassador and the visiting Vietnamese minister had said when the question was raised earlier this year as to whether Mr Downer had raised human rights questions in a meeting held just a few hours earlier with the Vietnamese ambassador. `Well', said Mr Howard—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: this is totally irrelevant to the question that was asked. You would know the question. The question was about ministerial integrity, Mr President, and I invite you to bring him back to the question, however embarrassing it might be to him.
—There is no point of order. The minister is entitled to answer the question.
—Thank you, Mr President. The question was put to Mr Howard how he could possibly explain this circumstance.
—What has this got to do with it?
—Well, you listen and you will understand. Mr Howard said:

ANSWER.PARA: Well, I have no doubt that the account that Alexander Downer gave to the meeting was correct.
Q. So you are basically saying that the Vietnamese Foreign Minister is lying.
No, I am not saying that. I mean people can come out of meetings with a different understanding.

Radio 5AA, 8 February 1995. That is Mr Howard's understanding of this particular issue. Of course, when there is no doubt that someone has been lying, Mr Howard takes a different tack. What about, for example—as appeared on Channel 9 news last Friday night—when he was reminded of Mr Tuckey's famous statement, `At times, I guess, by downright lying,' when asked how he handled things in terms of the leadership challenge. Mr Howard was asked how he responded to that. He stated:
Well, that did occur a very long time ago and it has not occurred while he has been a member of my frontbench.
What do you say, Mr Howard? Let me repeat it. When confronted with an acknowledgment that his own frontbench had lied, Mr Howard said, `That was a long time ago in a different place.' (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the face of it, the minister would seem to be walking away from his Prime Minister. I remind the minister of the basis of my question, which is what Mr Keating said in the House of Representatives last week. On the issue of rejecting the Western Australian royal commission, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: It is a kangaroo court, it is a crook commission.

Minister, now it seems that what you are saying is that you will not reject them. Is that the position, that you have now determined that it was unwise of the Prime Minister to have determined in advance that the findings would be rejected? Are you now saying to the Australian parliament that the findings, which include the findings on truth as determined by the royal commission, will be accepted by the government?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a wholly hypothetical question what the royal commission may find, and it is not a matter of anticipating any course of response at all in response to those findings. However, it is perfectly credible and sensible for the Prime Minister to say, as I have said and as all of us have said, that this is a royal commission unlike any royal commission that has ever previously been established, and anyone's reaction to its findings should have very close regard to the nature both of the motivation with which it was established and the nature of the task on which it was embarked. The nature of this particular royal commission's task is not to make a finding of criminality or financial impropriety or abuse of power or any of those things; it is to make a judgment about a particular course of events that occurred in a wholly political context, in a parliamentary context, a long time ago—as Mr Howard would be inclined to say `under those circumstances'. It is perfectly reasonable, under those circumstances, to approach this royal commission and anything associated with it with a very jaundiced view indeed. That is the approach we have adopted from day one, and that is the approach with which we will continue. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. There have been considerable media comments considering free trade within APEC. Press reports suggest that the Japanese are concerned about the impact of the comprehensiveness principle on their agricultural sector and have sought some flexibility. Are these reports correct? If so, what is the Australian government's position on the principle of comprehensiveness in APEC?

—I thank Senator Carr. Australia has made it clear to APEC, to all the APEC economies and most recently to Japan that the principle of comprehensiveness is a fundamental issue for Australia. It is vitally important that the action agenda we are currently developing to implement the APEC leaders' commitment to free trade and investment endorse the principle that there be no exceptions to the free trade and investment undertaking. To settle for less than this would undermine the credibility of APEC and would limit the opportunities APEC presents to our exporting communities.

PARA.TAB: As one of the most open trading regimes in the region, Australia stands to be one of the greatest beneficiaries of a general opening up of economies in the region. The most vulnerable to any exceptions would be agriculture, where protectionism remains high in the region. But there are other important industries that could be affected. Financial services, food processing, automotive parts, vehicles and processed minerals could also be disadvantaged if countries were allowed to carve out sectors and rules from the Bogor free trade and investment commitment.

For this reason we welcome the clear statement of support provided by Japanese ministers last Friday for the principle of comprehensiveness. It is correct that Japanese ministers raised the sensitive political consideration that the principle of comprehensive will have for their agricultural sector. There was no surprise in this for us. You would not have thought there was a surprise for anybody; but it seems it did come as a surprise to John Howard. The Leader of the Opposition comes thundering out today with a comment on this matter, as if it was some startling revelation.

Living in the ideal world of textbook trade and economic policy, you could argue that APEC economies should be able to see the overwhelmingly powerful argument in favour of a strict interpretation of the comprehensiveness principle. But we do not live in an ideal world. As a responsible government, one that is determined to deliver gains for Australia's export industries, including agriculture, we cannot venture into discussions in APEC with unrealistic and unrealisable objectives.

If we had determined, for example, as part of the final Uruguay Round package that all agricultural subsidies should be abolished, we would have lost the EU years ago and we would not have been able to achieve the very strong result—not the perfect result, but the very strong result—we did achieve for Australian agriculture. The industry would not have thanked us for setting unrealistic expectations.

Japan is in no doubt that we will not resile from the principle of comprehensiveness. But what we have said to them is that we recognise the difficulties they will face in opening up their agriculture sector to free trade and that while we cannot agree to exclude this sector, we recognise that the Bogor time frame and our proposal for individual action plans do provide the opportunity for APEC economies to stage their reduction commitments in a manner that helps accommodate their adjustment difficulties.

It is important to remember that they will, of course, need to provide compensatory early reductions in other sectors to balance delayed reductions in any others. There is great potential spin-off for Australia in that. The Leader of the Opposition does not seem to have realised this compensatory spin-off.

There is another point that seems to have been lost on those following a textbook approach: that is, APEC works by consensus. We cannot impose our will on APEC; we need to be looking for realistic outcomes. This is just another example of what people say about the two problems the opposition has in Asia. One is that nobody knows John Howard; the other is that everybody knows Tim Fischer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I have understood that in terms of those reports there have been complaints about the way the Australian government has handled this matter, in particular by our not taking a strict enough line on the question of comprehensiveness in free trade. What would be the implications for Australian workers if the government were to adopt the advice that has been proffered by the Leader of the Opposition?

—What we have here is Captain Zero in new clothes. While you can stand on the sideline and make comments about pushing for a purist position on freeing up APEC trade, we should not forget that the best possible outcome also has to accommodate Australia's sensitive sectors. We are not without them, of course. The obvious ones are TCF and automotive. I was discussing with the NFF this morning some sensitive agricultural sectors. If we went to that position, they would have to adapt to the principle of comprehensiveness.

PARA.TAB: So those who are arguing for a strict, uncompromising and unqualified—without any phasing—comprehensiveness position are effectively arguing that Australia has to bring TCF and automotive tariffs to zero in the same time frame that we are for all our less sensitive sectors. That is not what we are going to do. We are about acting in the national interest. Sometimes that means you cannot just follow the textbook. You cannot just be an independent commentator standing on the side, as if your comments had no impact on the lives of Australians. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister For Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. You and your government have repeatedly claimed, as you did yet again today in your answer to Senator Hill, that the Easton royal commission serves no useful purpose. Don't you agree—
—Of course it won't. You know that.

—I acknowledge that Senator Bolkus is interjecting, despite your references to him, Mr President. He agrees with that. The question is: don't you agree that the main findings of many royal commissions and, in particular, the WA Inc. royal commission, have been findings of improper conduct rather than illegal conduct; yet those very findings have uncovered grave deficiencies in the accountability of government? Don't you understand that the integrity and honesty of, as well as the motivation for, executive action is of central importance to the workings of our government systems and is, therefore, the proper subject of a royal commission?

—It is not entirely true, I have to frankly concede, that the royal commission in Western Australia serves no useful purpose. It has obviously served a very useful purpose for the Court government in operating as a major source of distraction from the events in Western Australia they have got themselves caught up in so far as Senator Noel Crichton-Browne is concerned. It is obviously a very useful exercise so far as John Howard and the opposition are concerned in diverting public attention away from their spectacular inability to come up with any positive policy responses on anything that Australians are genuinely interested in. Of course it has got a utility as a diversionary political tactic of a peculiarly squalid kind, and if you want to live with and enjoy that particular reputation for engaging in and supporting those tactics you can live with that in the court of public opinion.

PARA.TAB: As to the rest of your question, of course matters of integrity and honesty are crucial for governments to maintain their credibility. It is crucial that governments maintain the highest possible standards in this respect. All of us have frankly conceded that. All of us live by that rule and some people in the past have perished as a result of the application of that rule, politically speaking. But the point remains that these are matters to be determined when they do not involve criminality, when they do not involve abuse of power, when they do not involve financial impropriety, when they do not involve national security breaches or any of the things that have always justified royal commissions in the past and which have never allowed royal commissions to go beyond that. I cannot think of a single royal commission—and you have not had time to come up with one in all your research—that is in any way going down this particular path.

When questions of this kind have arisen in the past as to whether or not someone may have misled the parliament or the public on some issue not going to financial impropriety or criminality or any of the other things I have mentioned, they have been dealt with in the ordinary way—in the court of public opinion, on the floor of the parliament through no-confidence and other appropriate procedures in the parliament and by executive governments themselves, who of course have to live by that standard of honesty and integrity and suffer politically if they do not. That is the way these issues have been dealt with in the past. That is the way this issue should have been dealt with. That is the way it will be dealt with so far as this government is concerned.

We do not need a royal commission going down the path that this one has gone down, with all the indefensibility of its processes, its procedures, its motivation, in the way that this one has been set up. It is a travesty of any decent process. It is a clear-cut, unashamed exercise in political point scoring and an attempt to mount a political assault on a minister whose integrity has been absolutely unquestioned by the Australian community. You cannot stand the prospect of going into an election with a minister like that standing up there against you, so you are going down every squalid, sordid, miserable, backhanded path that you can. We have got absolutely nothing to be ashamed of or concerned about or worried about in the way in which we have handled this issue. We know the standards that are applicable in public life in this country. It is you that have got to learn a lesson about those standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The minister would be aware of the intense interest, particularly in the scientific community, in the mortality of pilchards off Australian and New Zealand early this year. Can the Minister advise on any progress both here and in New Zealand in determining what caused the deaths?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators would be aware, the pilchard mortality task force presented its interim report on pilchard kills in Australian waters on 26 June, and that report was made immediately public. I am advised that the report represents the agreed views of over 40 Australian scientists. The scientists were drawn from the Animal Quarantine Inspection Service, the Australian Animal Health Laboratories at Geelong, the CSIRO, the Victorian Institute of Animal Science and all state fisheries and veterinary authorities. The task force concluded that the underlying causes of the mortalities were complex and related to a number of factors. A likely hypothesis is that the initial factors involve stress associated with environmental changes, coupled with agents such as a herpes-like viral infection and/or amoebic infestations.

PARA.TAB: The interim report also stated that, whilst it could not be discounted, there was no evidence for or against the implication of an exotic pathogen in the pilchard mortalities. The jury is still out in Australia as far as the scientific community is concerned in terms of a conclusive finding. Indeed, it is quite a scientific challenge, when you consider the techniques that are involved and being developed, to come down with a conclusion.

However, I can inform the Senate that the New Zealand Ministry for Agriculture and Fisheries has now lifted the suspension it imposed on the import of Australian pilchards for use as bait or fish food. I am advised the suspension was imposed on 2 June as a precaution and followed media reports in Australia that the cause of mortalities was an exotic pathogen introduced in imported fish from North America.

The federal government has been advised by the Chief Veterinary Officer of the New Zealand Ministry for Agriculture and Fisheries regulatory authority, Mr Barry O'Neil, that the suspension of imported pilchards from Australia has been rescinded. In that written advice, he says:

ANSWER.PARA: MAFRA considers the mortalities in New Zealand pilchards to have been caused by a herpes virus enzootic as a latent infection in pilchards in the Oceania region.
In other words, that it is a latent herpes virus, as far as the New Zealand authority is concerned, and not an exotic pathogen.

PARA.TAB: Mr O'Neil has also advised that MAFRA is about to begin a review to assist the development of a consistent approach to managing the aquatic animal health risks posed by the importation of aquatic animals and their products into New Zealand. In other words, the New Zealand authorities are about to begin a process which AQIS here in Australia began in 1992 when it commissioned the BRS to do precisely that in 1992. As senators would be aware, that review has just been completed by the BRS in Australia and its findings are currently being assessed by a national task force on imported fish and fish products. I will continue to keep the Senate advised on this important issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Why is Australia not supporting a total ban on the production, stockpiling, export and use of all landmines, as are the UN Secretary-General, Pope John Paul II and numerous countries such as Austria, Belgium, Cambodia, Ireland, Mexico and Sweden? What is it about Australians which makes the government think that it is less important to us here to start negotiations at the upcoming Inhumane Weapons Convention Review Conference from a lesser position than that of a total ban?

—It needs to be understood that Australia is supporting a total ban on the production, stockpiling, export and use of all the kinds of landmines that have caused the appalling destruction of lives and limbs that we are all so unhappily conscious of. What we are supporting, because we think it is realistically achievable, is an absolute ban on the production, stockpiling, and sale, and so on, of any landmine which is non-self-destructing and non-self-utilising—a long-life mine. It is those that have caused the problems in the past when they have been sowed indiscriminately right across battlefields, have been unable to be detected, have not been properly mapped and have caused awful disasters. We are deeply concerned about the injuries to civilians which have been caused by the indiscriminate use and lingering presence of anti-personnel landmines, and that has obviously been one of the most tragic aftermaths of war in countries like Afghanistan, Cambodia, Angola and Mozambique.

PARA.TAB: We have been among those countries which have been right at the cutting edge, among those most active, in seeking a new approach internationally under the Inhumane Weapons Convention, which is to have its first review in a few days time, next month. We have pursued a two-pronged strategy essentially to the problem: firstly, the removal of already laid mines, which is obviously a huge priority, and, secondly, strengthening international rules on future use and trade.

What we want to do, what our overriding objective is at this conference, is to achieve real and immediate results which will have real and immediate impacts in terms of saving lives. Of course we are sympathetic to the long-term objective of eliminating completely anti-personnel mines. Last year, for example, we supported a UN General Assembly resolution that affirmed `the ultimate goal of the eventual elimination of anti-personnel landmines as viable, humane alternatives are developed'. But the reality is that there is simply no prospect whatsoever of achieving a total ban on all classes of landmines at this stage, in particular certainly at this review conference.

What we do think there is a chance of achieving is the following: first, I repeat, a ban on anti-personnel mines that lack a self-destruct or self-deactivating mechanism. To do that would be a huge step forward, solving—if we could do it—overwhelmingly the major problems so far as civilians are concerned. The argument that these are very technically complex to produce, very expensive to produce and are as impractical as we are saying a total ban would be simply does not stand up. There are simply degradability elements that you can put into the production of these things which make them neutralise, even if they do not self-destruct in the sense of blowing themselves up, after a relatively short period of time.

Secondly, we are also seeking to restrict transfers of short-lived landmines to states which are parties to the Inhumane Weapons Convention to allow nobody else but them to have them. We are seeking an extension of the convention's provisions to cover internal conflicts because, of course, it is internal conflicts that have been, overwhelmingly in recent years, the worst source of problems of this kind.

On the question of unexploded existing landmines, we will be contributing in excess of $5 million this year to de-mining and rehabilitation activities. Defence has been very actively involved in all these questions of that sort of assistance for a number of years now.

The trouble with a total ban on all forms of mines, not just the non-self-neutralising ones, is that most countries around the world regard them as legitimate weapons against potential enemy combatants, not only in the stable protection of borders and so on but also static installations or fixed installations in war time. And countries right around the world regard these as weapons no different in kind than machine-guns or artillery or any of the other conventional weapons that are capable of causing destruction. You have to find a way of getting them to accept the principle of not using any mines which, if not picked up after the event, can cause massive civilian damage.

We believe that the approach that we have adopted really goes much more closely to the heart of the real problem as it exists and gives us a much better chance of finding a solution than any of the other alternatives. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his answer which, as far as it goes, was very good. But the question that we all have to ask ourselves is: what is wrong with using a total ban as our starting point, and if we do not get the total ban then go down to what the minister is using as the starting point?

—I have said that we have supported language which talks in terms of that as an ultimate goal, provided there is some other defence mechanism that can be then invented to do the sort of job that landmines do and that has a chance of being accepted as a viable or humane alternative.

PARA.TAB: It is different in that sense from nuclear weapons. We have committed ourselves unequivocally to the absolute elimination of nuclear weapons in a way that we have not committed ourselves absolutely to the elimination of all forms of landmines. But the reason is that, whereas there is no defensive justification, no military justification, for nuclear weapons that does not constitute a worse evil than their continued existence—and we are wholeheartedly committed to that however long it takes to achieve—there is a problem in the reality of what armies need to defend themselves with in static defence positions. Unless you and others who take the total ban position—not even accepting this limited category that we are talking about—work out an alternative, viable way of giving defence people a legitimate form of defence that covers that same ground—(Time expired)

Can the minister inform the Senate of concerns raised at the conference in relation to community child-care services in Victoria and their future under the present Victorian government?

PARA.TAB: In Victoria in particular councils have had a long tradition of involvement in community services and in particular in child care.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order: I know that Mr Kennett appointed some very good quality people to his ministry a couple of years ago, but I can't remember Senator Crowley being appointed to it. Furthermore, I don't think any part of Senator Reynolds's question related to any part of her responsibility as a minister in the Keating government.
—I listened to the question and I thought that it was clearly a question which was asking for the impact in a particular state on federal policy, and I allowed the question on that basis.

—If the honourable senator holds his breath for one minute, he will understand precisely why it is within the responsibility of the Commonwealth. At a recent parents forum in Melbourne hosted by the National Parents Council on Child Care, many of the parents there expressed their anger and anxiety about what is happening to child care in the local government area in Victoria. PARA.TAB: The problem is that we have a very significant change under way in the local government area in Victoria. The consequence of that is a very dramatic effect on the child-care services delivered by local government. We have providers who are now in a process of anxiety, confusion and concern. We have families that are—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Now that Senator Crowley is well advanced into her answer to this question, I point out that it relates almost entirely to state government policy and is, therefore, well outside Senator Crowley's province.

—On the point of order: these state government changes in Victoria directly impact on the provision of Commonwealth subsidies for child care. If that is not relevant to this minister's portfolio, what is?
—There is no point of order.

—It is interesting to note just how touchy colleagues on the other side are about this, and so they ought to be. Parents and families in Victoria are very anxious and concerned about it, as are the providers of child-care services in this area.

PARA.TAB: Early this year, the Victorian government at last signed the national child-care strategy for an extra 5,000 child-care places in Victoria. But, with many of the councils being very reluctant to take on new child-care services in this long interim period of confusion and chaos there, thousands of those places are at risk of being lost to the Victorian people. Certainly, if they ever come on stream, it will be after an even further wait.

There is a demand for child-care places. There is a concern that services be provided. There is also a great concern that the services that are there be not confused, changed and altered in a way that makes it very upsetting and puzzling for families. What families want more than anything is a sense of ongoing security about those child-care places. At the moment in Victoria, that is exactly what they do not have. Mr Kennett wants to erode local government and state government involvement in child care. In that way, he is just like Mr Malcolm Fraser, who steadily eroded the Commonwealth government's involvement in child care when he was Prime Minister. At the time, Mr Howard was Treasurer. Unfortunately, no-one knows what he will do about child care.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer to the report in the Australian three weeks ago that the government is reviewing its quarantine import policy following industry complaints over the risks of introduced pests and disease. In light of the review, what is the government's position to changes in the pipeline for imported salmon, chicken meat, egg products and pork? When will the government announce its decision on any changes to its policy?

—The government has regularly reviewed quarantine operations in Australia over the years, and so it should. One reason, apart from the changing nature of our trade and our industries—we are now importing and exporting goods that we did not import and export 10 years ago—is that there is a dramatically changing face in terms of the science and body of knowledge that is available from time to time on those issues. That is why a regular review is necessary.

PARA.TAB: The last time that the quarantine policy was reviewed in Australia was as a result of a committee being established by John Kerin in 1987. That committee was chaired by Professor David Lindsay, who was the professor of agriculture and dean of the faculty of agriculture at the University of Western Australia. The Lindsay committee brought down a report in 1988 recommending a number of changes to our quarantine regime that operated then. One recommendation of the Lindsay committee was that quarantine operations be reviewed again post 1994.

In terms of the current initiative, we are acting on a recommendation of the last review—that is, that post 1994 a further review be conducted. The Lindsay committee in its recommendations found, and emphasised the fact—and it is worth having a look at this in light of the controversy alleging a shift in basic quarantine policy in Australia to negligible risk; there has never been a policy of zero risk in Australia and commonsense would tell you why there has not been—that all movements of people and goods into Australia involve some risk of introduction of exotic pests and diseases, however small.

Quarantinable pests and diseases can be carried on or in the clothes or bodies of international air travellers or on or in any imported cargo or mail coming into Australia. The only way you could reduce those risks to zero would be by halting all international traffic. Of course, a major trading nation such as Australia is not about to do that.

As I have said, one of the important recommendations of the Lindsay committee was that there should be a review every four or five years and that there certainly should be a review post 1994. We are simply implementing that recommendation. In respect of the impact of the review on procedures currently under way, I point out that those procedures will continue.

In respect of salmon, a major exercise is now under way to examine the many submissions that were received during the 60 day draft risk analysis procedure which is provided for under the act. A number of major submissions have been received, principally from the industry in Tasmania and the Tasmanian department, which are currently being examined.

The pork industry accepted an offer I made to them to involve the Industry Commission in an examination of the allegations of an impact of Canadian pork on the Australian market. They consulted with the government on the terms of reference drawn up for that Industry Commission investigation which is now under way. We should have a report from the Industry Commission on that matter before the end of the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid I did not get any joy from the answer to that question. The minister is obviously not prepared to say that he is going to take any action in relation to the importation of these products. I did ask the minister when will the government announce its decision. He went round and round the mulberry bush on that one. Seeing that you will not make a decision on whether you will or will not stop these imports coming in—
—Is that what you want to do, Ron?

—I am quoting what you said in the Australian. I ask: considering the strong warnings from both science and industry groups on present quarantine policy, would the government be prepared to accept full responsibility for any damage to Australia's primary industries from any introduced diseases or pests, as a result of the government's present quarantine policy?

—It is an interesting taste of quarantine policy under a coalition government if Senator Boswell has any influence, which I imagine he would. Implicit in that question is the fact that the coalition would handle this by simply declaring that they would not import any of these items. That is what Senator Boswell invited me to say.

PARA.TAB: That would be an interesting position, Senator Boswell, as far as the primary producers in this country are concerned, because we are country which exports 80 per cent of everything our primary producers produce. We are world's biggest exporter of beef. We are the world's largest exporter of sugar. We are among the world's largest exporters of grain. I think it behoves a responsible government to handle these quarantine issues according to the procedures that are laid down and to fulfil our international obligations under them. Otherwise, it will be our primary producers who, at the end of the day, will suffer badly from the kind of knee-jerk approach to quarantine that Senator Boswell is advocating.(Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. When did ATSIC gain the status of the peak non-government organisation representing Australia's indigenous people before the United Nations? How does the minister explain ATSIC's claim to NGO status when it is clear that ATSIC remains a statutory authority of the Commonwealth of Australia? How does the government justify allowing one of its own government authorities to be recognised by the United Nations as an NGO?

—I would have thought ATSIC's acceptance as an NGO of world standing in stature whose voice will be heard on behalf of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, as an organisation representing those people before the highest councils of the world—in Geneva, New York and elsewhere—would be a matter of pride. There are only about a dozen indigenous organisations around the world that have that status, although there are some thousands of NGOs who have that status in other particular contexts, such as the environment and so on. But, so far as indigenous peoples are concerned, it really is a badge of honour; it reflects the standing in which ATSIC is held internationally.

PARA.TAB: I do not know what the precise criteria are for determining what is a non-government body for this purpose. Presumably there was no technical doubt about ATSIC satisfying that once it had been established at arms length as a statutory body in the way that it is—deliberately not as part of a government department and so on in the way that had been the case.

I do not know the precise sequence of events in respect of the criteria that were applied, but I will seek further information on that and advise the honourable senator. But I repeat, and I finish where I began: why are you always so miserably inclined so far as ATSIC is concerned? Treat it as an organisation of pride which is genuinely reflecting the overwhelming majority of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to restrain myself from commenting on the minister's answer so far. Minister, where does the acceptance of ATSIC as an NGO by the UN leave indigenous Australians who wish to take issues about their treatment by the Australian government to the UN? How does this match with desires for indigenous self-determination? Are you seriously arguing, therefore, that ATSIC is a non-government organisation?

—I will seek further information on the matters which you raise. I am not sure precisely how the UN processes work. All I know is that when these large conferences occur there does not seem to be any particular inhibition on the capacity of the UN system to absorb representations from innumerable organisations of all stripes and colours. I would be very surprised if other organisations do not get a voice in that same context. I will try to give you the information you want. Whether it is enough to satisfy you is another question.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the report?

PARA.TAB: It is very close to concluding all of this. I might say that it has been a commendable effort by Dr Roy Green, the chief executive of the CSIRO. What I am asked by Senator Ferguson is this: are we ignoring the Senate's report? We are aware of the Senate's report. PARA.TAB: I might say, Mr President, that honourable senators would have noticed in recent weeks the appointment of Dr Malcolm McIntosh as chief executive officer of the CSIRO. TALK.START.PARA: —Given that the government accepted the standard of three months as the time in which to reply to a committee report, I would ask the minister in the light of his answer to that question: what does he consider an appropriate time, considering that nine months has already transpired since the report was laid down in the Senate?

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Is it a fact that the navy has decided not to use Windows 95 because serious lack of security is associated with the use of this software? —I think this question would be better directed—even by way of a letter, Senator—to the Minister for Finance, who I think is the responsible minister for the chief information officer recently appointed by the government. By checking around today, I understand you have to make a conscious decision before any information can go out. But, as I say, it is not one of my fields of expertise. —My question is to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer to the minister's statement last week announcing a review of the current drought assistance measures. It is appropriate to review the operation of the program after a year, which, I might add, was also endorsed by all primary industry ministers.

As part of that review, an examination will be made of the contribution that has been made to drought affected farmers by state governments. One of the difficulties in providing a comprehensive scheme of assistance to farmers at the national level is that there are wide variations, as Senator Brownhill knows, between the approach that is made by the states to drought.

Of course, it is the states which deliver our programs on our behalf. The reference that is made to rainfall—it is an important enhancement of the criteria—is that effective rainfall has been agreed as being the determinant.

Senator McMullan interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —He is the leader, Senator McMullan, and I suppose if anyone knows he would. I guess primary producers in Australia will still have to wait for that. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. I refer to reports in the media relating to proposals for tax cuts for small business. Yes, I have seen the reports that appeared in the papers over the weekend—in particular, what appears to be an inspired leak from the Liberal Party of a long document outlining what tax changes they would supposedly offer to small business. Tax is an area that in one fell swoop would put the present budget surplus back into deficit. What would that do? That would put pressure on interest rates to go up in Australia. As any of the small business organisations will tell you—this is the No.1 issue—the one thing they do not want is increases in interest rates, because that is a daily cost on their bottom line. So what we have here from the opposition is a suggestion of a whole range of tax cuts that would put the budget surplus into deficit, that would put pressure on interest rates to go up and that, therefore, would make a much bigger impact on the profitability of small business than any of the so-called tax cuts.

In the press a day later I noticed that a spokesman for Mr Howard said, `No, this is only a policy options paper; we haven't made up our minds'. Each of them will be properly costed and each of them will be an issue of substance into which the small business community will have had an opportunity to have a proper input. It will not be like this wish list that the shadow minister has released, knowing full well that, closer to an election, they will let it all be pulled back. But, by that stage, they will have misled the small business community.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission

TALK.START.PARA: —During question time, Senator Chamarette asked me a question about the NGO status of ATSIC before the United Nations. If she is interested, I will be happy to give her a full answer. The situation is this. ATSIC made application for UN NGO status according to standard UN procedures. It provided full information on its legal status in Australia, its structure and its financial arrangements. The application was considered by the UN NGO committee in June this year in New York. Two ATSIC officials attended the meeting and responded to the committee's questions, of which I understand there were quite a few. On the basis of that application and full evaluation of it, the NGO committee approved the granting of that status on 19 June.

PARA.TAB: ATSIC's status within the UN is, of course, a matter for the UN. The granting of that status by the NGO committee has application only within UN organisations; it has no wider significance. However, as I said earlier on, we do believe that that status will be a useful way of emphasising the unique and positive arrangements developed in Australia for returning decision-making powers to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people within a representative framework.

As to what is the significance of this status for ATSIC as compared with other organisations, to participate in higher level UN human rights bodies such as the Commission on Human Rights itself, an NGO does require formal status. Several thousand NGOs have such status. They are from every part of the world and collectively cover the full range of economic and social issues of relevance to the UN. In the indigenous area, as I said there are only 12 organisations, however, representing indigenous people around the world. Only one of those, apart from ATSIC, is from Australia, and that is NAILS—the National Aboriginal and Islander Legal Services secretariat.

Until this year, however, ATSIC's participation in UN meetings on indigenous issues has been possible to a certain extent, notwithstanding that it lacked formal UN and NGO status. It has been able to participate, for example, in the working group on indigenous populations and so on even without that formal status. So the reasoning, equally, would apply to other organisations which, I guess, want to make an effort to participate before them.

Finally, the government supports the participation by Australia's indigenous peoples and relevant UN bodies. We have been aware of ATSIC's application for some time. We are also willing to provide information and assistance to other Aboriginal organisations in Australia which may wish to seek that status. We would be very happy to provide the kind of support that we provided to ATSIC to any recognised Australian indigenous NGO seeking that status. We will be as helpful as we can be.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Wednesday of last week, Senator MacGibbon asked me whether changes to IVF policies for ADF members were required as a result of pressure from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission or to comply with HREOC legislation. The answer to that is categorically no. Health care of servicewomen is a responsibility of the Australian Defence Force. Unlike their civilian counterparts, who are able to claim for IVF treatment under Medicare, servicewomen do not have the ability to claim for such treatment. For those women who choose to pursue treatment under the IVF program, the matter of their infertility is, of course, one of great personal concern. The ADF certainly did not want servicewomen leaving the defence forces just so they could take part in the IVF program. A revised policy on the provision of IVF programs for ADF members was introduced in January 1995 to remove the injunction against IVF and to redress that previous inequity.

PARA.TAB: Senator MacGibbon also asked me whether there was a specific proposal to allocate $1 million in the 1995-96 defence budget for the cost of IVF for ADF members. Again, the answer is no. Indicative costs of the revised policy were developed by the services. However, these figures remain highly uncertain as the number of ADF servicewomen who might meet the clinical requirements for the assisted fertilisation is unknown, as is the number of treatment cycles and therefore the cost of what each may require.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Brownhill this day, relating to drought.

Some decisions need to be made about a visible assessment, because in many circumstances it is impossible to actually put scientific criteria to what is a drought.

Senator Collins spent some time today talking about the rainfall data situation. Nobody is going to argue with what he said. But I will say this: the problem with using rainfall data is that there are so many other circumstances that come into play which make a smaller amount of rain either very valuable or absolutely useless—for example, temperature, wind and the time of the season the rain falls. It is a very imprecise science of determining whether or not that rainfall really means anything.

The government—with the review by the states; and the states have responded in different ways—are now relying too much today, when determining what is required, on so-called scientific theory in their response to the drought as against going out there, having a look and giving somebody the responsibility of determining what is required in the drought. That is the area in which I condemn very severely this government's response to the drought.

Senator Collins also made some reference today to Mr Howard's address to the cattlemen's conference at Roma. As I understand it, Mr Howard said today that dealing with this problem required a bipartisan approach, not the sort of reaction we got from Senator Collins in here today when he came in and thought he could just belt the coalition over the head word after word and refuse to address the question that was put to him. I challenge Senator Collins to come back into this place and to address the question that was put to him today. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I concur with everything that Senator Crane has just said. One of the problems at the moment is that we have quite an horrific circumstance about to recur in some places and continue to occur in places in both southern Queensland and northern New South Wales—and the drought is slowly moving south. The rural areas have had problems of rainfall, and some areas have had the problems of mice which have actually taken crops from some of the farmers.

PARA.TAB: I am very disappointed that the minister did not answer the question a little better than he did. In fact, he did not answer one part of it at all: when will the review be completed? He did not tell us when that was to be completed, which is a bit unfortunate because a lot of people out there want to know what is going to happen.

Senator Crane has already said that this is something that needs a bipartisan look at because it is just not working quite as well as it should be. Late in May, a few areas in the central west of New South Wales were added to the other areas on the list of exceptional circumstances. The new people who have been included in those areas will access some federal drought relief in the form of drought relief payments and assistance through the Rural Assistance Authority. Those people will get some help.

In the last little bit—in May—some people actually got some rain and because of that they got a little bit too much rain. They were just about to go into exceptional circumstances and now, because of that little bit of rain, they have sown a crop and they have not met the effective rainfall criteria and they have been denied access to the assistance. The thing about it is that a little bit of rain then made people sow crops. But they do not get the money until they harvest the crops and there is a great likelihood that there will be no crops in some of those places because already in some of those areas the crops have been written off.Even in the south of the state in some of the areas where they are not in exceptional circumstances they may not get a crop, so there will be big problems there.

I also asked the minister whether he was satisfied that the effective rainfall formula devised by his department accurately identifies those areas in most need. I do not think he answered that question either. As Senator McGauran said, it was really not the sort of answer to a question that Senator Collins sometimes can give. I do not think he really gets the guts of what is actually happening at the moment out there and I also do not think he gets the guts of how the formula is meant to work.

We have had meetings with people from his department. We have been told that you go through the meteorological threshold first and then look at the economic conditions, environment and natural resource issues, the water supplies, the farm income levels and the scale of the event. But with all that taken into account, if the first criterion is going to be just the rainfall, people can have all the other criteria there, basically, and if they do not get across that first threshold they do not get any further with it and they are left right out in the cold as far as help and assistance are concerned.

I would just ask the minister to go back and look at the answer that he gave, look at the question that was asked and then come up with some better answer. He may be able to come back tomorrow, or he may even be able to come into the adjournment debate tonight and tell us what he is going to do to make the criteria a little bit fairer, a little bit more equitable and a little better for those people who are desperately going to need help and assistance in the future—people who absolutely, desperately need help at this very moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I briefly also address this subject mainly from the position of Western Australia. I believe myself that scientific theory more than scientific evidence is used far too much to determine whether there is a drought or not.

PARA.TAB: During question time it was amusing to hear Senator Bob Collins say that rainfall has something to do with drought—`and let no-one ever forget it'. Rain does make a bigger difference at different times of the year. For instance, even a mediocre level of rainfall right across Western Australia would make a big difference to the dollars right now, whereas three times that level of rainfall in the middle of winter would not make anywhere near so much difference. Of course, that reasonable level of rainfall and the big dollar difference would affect the government's balance of trade and export income.

The reason for rising, mostly, is once again to put in front of the Senate the situation of the East Gascoyne areas of Western Australia which this year came out of four consecutive droughts. The government has steadfastly refused to agree to even look at the situation. I think that Senator Collins did say that an inspector or someone went over to look, but I do not think he got within 1,000 kilometres of the East Gascoyne area. But having had, to my knowledge, those four consecutive droughts, they got a massive drought breaking level of rainfall this year. Of course, rainfall has a much different effect in pastoral areas than it does on agricultural areas. Agricultural areas need rain every year, whereas one massive rainfall can set up a pastoral area for three years.

Unfortunately, those people cannot afford to restock at this stage. It is a well-known saying in the agricultural and pastoral areas that, when it rains, it does not necessarily rain dollars. The dollars hopefully come in 12 months or so. These people need help to restock. They are set up for this season and the next two. The government has refused time and again to look at it. In that region, since the inception of the pastoral industry about 100 years ago, there has never been a forced sale. I am talking about the east Gascoyne. I am not talking about the Murchison area or anywhere else. So it is a pretty solid industry.

As I have said once before in this place, their source of finance is limited, because banks do not normally finance the pastoral industry. It is financed by stock firms, such as Elders and Dalgety, et cetera. It is time that I ask this Senate and the minister to look at both the situation of those in the Gascoyne area of Western Australia and the drought declaration provisions once again.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Boswell this day, relating to quarantine.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister did not answer Senator Boswell's question about an important matter of primary industry. Like my colleague Senator Brownhill, I invite the minister to come in on the adjournment debate and answer Senator Brownhill's question and Senator Boswell's most serious question. It seems to be a trait of this minister, Senator Collins, to not get to the core of this issue. Either he is not across his portfolio and has no affinity with the primary industry sector, which is what I suspect, or he simply wants to avoid the truth of the matter in the government's handling of the drought and the quarantine issue.

PARA.TAB: The essence of Senator Boswell's question is this: now that the government is undertaking a review of its quarantine policies under pressure due to the complaints in this house and by the representative bodies with regard to the possible risks of pests and disease, when will that review be ready? This is not a review that can be long and drawn out. It is a review of urgency. The longer it is drawn out, the more likely it is that some disease or pest will enter this country and wipe out a whole industry.

If nothing else, we call upon Senator Collins to give us a date when this review will be completed. It is of the utmost importance. If you are a government presently running a quarantine policy of minimum risk, you are laying open every primary industry in this country to the risk of disease or pests. We need a quick review and a date to be able to settle on the tabling of that review.

It particularly involves the pig industry. I recognise that Senator Baume is in the chamber. He also has a great interest in the pig industry. The pig industry awaits this review probably more than any other primary industry. The pig industry has been under enormous pressure of late. It has been compounded by the drought. Seventy per cent of its costs are grain costs. Grain costs have increased remarkably during the period of the drought.

It has been unable to compete with Canadian imports, which are cross-subsidised by the Canadian government. To that end, we saw some months ago protests by the pig industry that brought 800 farmers to Parliament House. They stacked out the galleries to highlight their concerns with regard to the subsidised products being allowed into this country. The government sits back and allows this to occur while not enforcing the highest standards in quarantine.

There are many concerns regarding the possibility of diseases and pests entering this country. You only have to look at the beef industry to find an example. For years, the beef industry has had a competitive advantage over its main competitor, South America. South America is riddled with footrot. We have been able to sell a clean product to the United States and other parts of the world simply because this country is footrot free.

Over the years, if there has been a possibility of footrot entering this country or the slightest hint of an outbreak, quarantine officers have, with good reputation, moved in swiftly to eliminate that possibility. They have wiped out whole herds—and not necessarily those with footrot but those within miles of the notified disease.

That is a good example of how the quarantine laws work and why they should be there. The beef industry has been able to sell its product and enter new markets on the basis that we have good quarantine laws. In this case, the pig industry is in danger of diseases and pests from Canadian imports ruining any competitive advantage it might have.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Alston (from 400 citizens), Senator Short (from 411 citizens) and Senator Spindler (from 600 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

Intensive logging, most often to feed a voracious woodchip industry is underway or planned for many high conservation value forests. These forests should be protected by the commitments of the Commonwealth and State Governments under the NFPS.
These forests include:

PETITION.PARA: Coolangubra Wilderness and other areas of the S.E. Forests of NSW along with rainforest and other N.E. areas of NSW including Wingham, Mistake, Richmond Range, Chaelundi, North Washpool, Barrington and Dorrigo.
The Southern Forests, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness of Tasmania.
The Karri and Jarrah forests of S.W. Western Australia.
The Errinundra Plateau and other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: We request that the Government act urgently to protect our precious forests by utilising the Commonwealth's legal and constitutional powers, including:

PETITION.PARA: Refusal of export woodchip licences
Powers to control corporations
Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate
Protection and effective funding of areas identified for their World Heritage values.

PARA.TAB: Genuine and effective action by the Government to protect these and other old growth and wilderness forests is critical. A comprehensive plantation strategy rather than exploiting native forests is the way forward for a truly environmentally responsible timber industry. We further request that the Government take effective action without further delay.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are opposed to the sex guide endorsed by Ms Lawrence, Minister for Health in the Keating Government, and published in the December issue of Cleo.
2.We believe that the sex guide encourages dangerous sexual practices which could have serious medical and moral effects.

PARA.TAB: We request the Senate to call on Ms Lawrence to withdraw her endorsement of this sex guide and for the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to indicate his disapproval.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows: the injust and inequitable nature of the Government's policy to restrict Childcare Assistance where a parent is outside the workforce to 12 hours per week. This policy will cause hardship to lower income families, to the children of those families, and child care workers. The Government should be condemned for breaking its promise to ensure access and affordability in child care.

Under the Government's policy parents will have to pay full cost fees after 12 hours of childcare per week if one parent is outside the workforce. This will widen the gap between rich and poor, and many child care workers may lose their jobs.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the Senate should oppose the passage of this Bill into law.

PETITION.TITLE: Landmines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows that we are;

disturbed by the fact that every month between 600 and 1200 people (most of them civilians) are killed or maimed by landmines, and their health and maintenance costs are being incurred in countries with insufficient resources to meet the most basic needs of all their people,

concerned that the cost of clearing and de-activating of landmines is one hundred times the financial cost of manufacture, and the human cost is being borne by people who have suffered displacement, war, tribulation and hunger,

and we are greatly concerned that there remains between 85 and 100 million unexploded mines scattered over 62 different countries, inhibiting the ordinary movement of civilians and the farming of fields as people return to their former homes as wars cease.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:
ensure that the overseas aid budget contains a substantial allocation for de-mining training programs,
ensure that Australian Government delegations to International fora persuade more countries to become party to, and gratify, the Inhumane Weapons Convention

ensure that Australian Government delegations to International fora promote and support an amendment to Article 6 of Protocol II to prohibit the use, development, production, stockpiling and transfer of landmines.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: Australia's old growth forest and wilderness areas are being diminished as a result of continued logging. The Federal Government has granted new woodchip export licences despite its agreement for a moratorium on logging in high conservation areas.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should:

PETITION.PARA: apply conditions retrospectively to woodchip licences in order to meet Commonwealth obligations, and
exclude from licences, woodchip derived from old growth forests and wilderness areas.

PETITION.TITLE: Education: Freedom of Choice

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the Citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That we:
(1) Affirm the importance of quality education for all the children of this Commonwealth of Australia irrespective of their religion, nationality or sex;
(2) Support the rights of parents to have freedom of choice of the school for their child;
(3) Support the right of all non-government schools to maintain their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos;
(4) Support the freedom of choice in staffing of all Churches and religious organisations;
(5) Support freedom of religion and the right of all Churches and religious organisations to maintain their distinctive foundational ethos.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate oppose any attempts to introduce legislation that would jeopardise these freedoms and rights and which would force Schools, Churches and religious institutions to compromise their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos.
