TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matters be referred to the Legal and Constitutional References Committee for inquiry and report, in respect of paragraph (a) to (e) and (h), on or before 28 September 1995, and, in respect of paragraphs (f) and (g), on or before 26 October 1995:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)what is the legal basis for the decision to pay Dr Lawrence's legal costs in challenging the legality of aspects of the Marks' Royal Commission;
(b)what was the sequence of events leading to the Government's decision to pay such legal costs, in particular:

TAB.TAB: (i)who initiated the process leading to that decision and when and how was this done,
(ii)what official advice was sought and given about the proposal or any possible proposal to pay such costs, and
(iii)what advice or communications on the proposal or any possible proposal did the Government receive from what sources outside Government, including private lawyers or legal firms;

SPEECH.PARA: (c)what advice, from within or outside Government, was given, and what Government decisions were taken, in relation to the legal standing Dr Lawrence or any other person might have in any proceedings challenging the legality of the Marks' Royal Commission and what bearing did this have on the decision to pay the legal costs from public funds;
(d)what advice was given to Government, and what consideration was paid by Government, to the following:

TAB.TAB: (i)estimating the likely total financial liability of the Commonwealth arising from the Government's decision to pay legal costs,
(ii)whether any cap or limit should be placed on such expenditure, and
(iii)procedures to monitor the nature and growth of the Commonwealth's financial liability in the matter and the efficiency and effectiveness of the expenditure;

SPEECH.PARA: (e)bearing in mind that Government was funding the legal challenges from public funds, what role did Government play in relation to any of the legal challenges to the Marks' Royal Commission, including in relation to the decisions to challenge, or to appeal against lost challenges, and in relation to the nature of the arguments to be put to the respective courts on behalf of Dr Lawrence or any other person;
(f)what guidelines and conditions should be put in place to ensure the legality and propriety of any use of public funds to pay the legal costs of Ministers and members of parliament;

(g)what is the appropriate level of reporting to parliament on the use of public funds to pay the legal costs of Ministers and members of parliament including the reasons for the decision to provide such funds; and
(h)any other matter arising in the course of the inquiry which is relevant to the foregoing terms of reference, inquiry into which would facilitate reporting on those terms of reference.

In this motion there is one change from the motion perhaps now being circulated in the chamber, that is, a reporting date of 28 September for the majority of the references. This matter relates to what is being referred to as the Easton royal commission and, in particular, to the government's decision to fund Dr Lawrence's private legal costs in joining in an action to try to scuttle the Western Australian royal commission and, for that matter, to the Commonwealth's intervention in those proceedings.

PARA.TAB: The government would have us believe, as we have heard time and time again from the minister opposite, Senator Gareth Evans, that there is no point to this commission other than to get Dr Lawrence. So egocentric are the government and so high do they hold her in their regard that they cannot see that this commission has a legitimate basis. Western Australians are entitled to know the truth about a matter that has been of significant public concern in Western Australia. Perhaps not understood by those in other states is the degree to which this has become a topic of much interest and—more than interest—concern in Western Australia.

The Western Australian government have set up a properly constituted commission. I am yet to hear an argument that it is not properly constituted, despite attempts, I might say, of Mr Stephen Smith and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to intimidate any members of the judiciary or former members into not participating and accepting the job of commissioner and equally to try to intimidate members of the profession into not taking up jobs as counsel assisting or participating in any other way in this commission.

Nonetheless, despite those attempts to intimidate members of the profession and former members of the judiciary, the commission has been established, and, as I say, it is properly constituted. I note that a significant number of Western Australian parliamentarians and former parliamentarians acknowledge that it is properly constituted and have willingly and freely gone along and told what they believe to be the truth with respect to this matter.

We could say at that point, `Well, that's how it was going to go, and it is of no concern to us,' but, not long after the announcement of the commission, the federal government announced they would fund what I believe were then described as—and I may be wrong here; I do not have the press release of the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) in front of me—`Dr Lawrence's costs'. The inference was that the private legal action being taken out to challenge the authority of the commission was, in fact, Dr Lawrence's legal action.

We now know, of course, that that is a load of rubbish. We know that the Attorney knew at the time of putting out that release that Mr Halden was the one who had standing to issue those proceedings and that Dr Lawrence could not probably have issued them in her own right—that is how thin her interest, and how thin and feeble her association is with this matter. She could not run the proceedings to scuttle the commission herself.

So, somewhere in the dark recesses of Labor back rooms, an arrangement was made that Mr Halden would put his name to these proceedings if the work was all done pro bono. Mr Halden does not have the money to pay. I do not mind pro bono work. I wish the government recognised how much pro bono work the profession does. Then we find that Dr Lawrence is joining in this action—which she cannot run herself—and, surprise, surprise, Commonwealth taxpayers will be funding her. That does raise the question of the consideration the government gave to what benefits Mr Halden would be getting from this arrangement if, by a nudge and a wink, everybody was acting for Mr Halden for nothing.

There is a very serious question as to what information the government had at hand when it agreed to fund Dr Lawrence's legal fees. As I say, it is not Dr Lawrence's action—it is Mr Halden's action—but they are her legal fees. Did the government know at the time that someone else was going to get an enormous benefit out of this? Did they know at the time that Dr Lawrence probably could not have run these matters on her own?

That is what this inquiry is going to and that is what this Senate committee is being asked to look at; not whether or not Dr Lawrence lied. That is a matter for the commission, a matter for the Western Australian parliament and, primarily I suppose, a matter for Western Australian voters. I do not deny that it has now been raised to such a level that there may be other voters around the nation who will judge this government by their response to the commission. But that is impossible to say until the commission has had the chance to hear all parties concerned—let me rephrase it more generously—until Dr Lawrence has had the opportunity to put her case and those witnesses whom she claims will support her case have had the chance to be heard. But none of that is what this inquiry is about.

This inquiry is about why Commonwealth taxpayers' money, hard-earned taxpayers' money, should be used to fund a private legal action not in the name of a Commonwealth minister but by a Commonwealth minister joined in it to try to scuttle the executive action of another government. That is what this inquiry is about. It has nothing to do with whether or not Dr Lawrence told the truth. That is a matter for other forums than this committee.

This has everything to do with whether, once you are elected to government federally, you can sit behind those cabinet doors, make whatever agreements you like and disburse money willy-nilly, at large, as you will, without being accountable for it. What role does the Senate and the House of Representatives have in keeping a check on not only the payments that are made but also what they are payments for and the manner in which those decisions are arrived at. That is what we seek to get to here.

Is it true, as alleged or hinted at in the Australian newspaper, that former Senator Stephen Loosley—sometimes kindly referred to as Stephen `Let me at the money' Loosley—actually rang Dr Lawrence, contacted her in one way or another, and said, `Why don't we scuttle this commission?' Did they cook up a deal between themselves?

Who did approach the Commonwealth? Who first raised this in the Commonwealth? Madam Deputy President, if there were no concern about this, if the funding were straight down the line and 100 per cent above board, there would be no embarrassment in the government saying that this matter was first raised by the Attorney or by Dr Lawrence or by the Prime Minister. It is the old story: if you had nothing to hide, you would come forth with the truth.

We have tried. We tried a more reasonable path to get to the bottom of this matter. We tried, with the support of the Democrats and the Greens, to move a return to order to get some idea of how the government had come to this decision. What we got was a few paltry, pathetic press releases in response.

There are apparently no documents on this matter that the government is prepared to release, not even a note of a telephone conversation saying that Dr Lawrence rang the Attorney-General or that the Prime Minister rang the Attorney-General. Apparently, no meetings took place of which there would be notes. Because we did not receive a document which gave a notice of meeting between X number of parties and then the details crossed out, we are not even entitled to know who met with whom and on what days. That is the level of secrecy that this government has put around its decision to fund Dr Lawrence joining Mr Halden in this legal action.

We tried an appropriate way. The government had the opportunity. I do not mean to say that it was the only appropriate way, but we tried it and we got nothing back of any use whatsoever. The government may be able to say, with respect to its legal advice as to the likelihood of the proceedings being successful, that it wants to claim privilege with respect to that legal advice. That is a debate that you could easily have, and there would probably be quite a lot of support for that. But there is no support whatsoever for saying that every other document associated with this decision to fund should be locked away, and that we, the parliament, will have only that which either the minister opposite, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), the Attorney, or whoever, decides we will have and that they will be accountable to parliament as they choose and not as parliament wants. We have already had that in the form of Labor ministers basically telling the Senate that it can go and have a picnic lunch and do something else. They have no desire to come forward with these documents.

We are left in no other position than to say, `Well, we will have to refer this matter to a committee.' We tried a more efficient and cost-effective way, a less time-consuming way—a way, quite frankly, that I think would have focused much less publicity on the government's disastrous decision to fund Dr Lawrence's legal costs and much less publicity on Dr Lawrence. Do not let anybody who gets up to speak on this matter pretend that the purpose of sending this to a committee is somehow to add to the pile who wish to get at Dr Lawrence. The opportunity was there to evade this; the opportunity was there to answer first off, but that opportunity was passed by—not by people on this side, but by members of the government.

It is important to understand, if it is not obvious to everyone concerned already, that the commission in Western Australia does not have any association whatsoever with matters pertaining to Dr Lawrence's functions as a federal member or as a federal minister. The matters before that commission relate entirely to things that happened before she got into federal parliament. Let us also not hear from the government that somehow they are entitled to spend this money as they wish because it is assisting a minister in performing her functions. A year-12 legal studies student would not swallow that load of rubbish.

Appearing before the commission is something that, if I were Dr Lawrence, I would have done. I would have simply gone along and, if I had wanted to raise the matter of parliamentary privilege, I would have chosen that as the forum to do so. But, no; for some reason yet to be explained it had to be done another way. Of course, it always has to be done one particular way, and that is Dr Lawrence's way. We have discovered that in the past.

Nonetheless, we had a situation where, for one reason or another, private legal proceedings were being raised—not by Dr Lawrence because she did not have the standing to do it, but by Mr Halden—and the government was agreeing to pay. We say that we are not confident that this money in any way relates to her functions as a minister—not at all. It is just a free tipping of the bucket of money accessible to the executive, for one of their mates, with a quite inadequate explanation. We say that in all probability it is in breach of the constitution. You see, the minister opposite can wave around the Parliamentary Entitlements Act as much as he likes but, if the payments do not fit that act—if they cannot properly be described as attaching to that act—and if there is not enough power in the relevant parts of the constitution for that act to do what the minister says ought to be done, well, tough chips. It is an unconstitutional act by the government. They are the matters that we think need to be very carefully addressed.

The first matter I have tried to highlight is what is the legal basis for the decision to pay Dr Lawrence's legal costs in challenging the legality of aspects of the Marks royal commission. I think it is very important to look at the constitutionality of the payments and the propriety of them. I have also tried to highlight the dark secrecy that there is around how the government came to this decision. What is the problem? If there is nothing wrong with former Senator Loosley cooking up a deal and approaching someone—and I do not see that there is anything wrong with him ringing and saying, `Look, I think I can find a way for you to scuttle this'—then to top it off by getting the taxpayer to pay for this is something that raises my very strong interest.

We want to know who initiated the process leading to that decision, and when and how it was made. We want to know what official advice was sought and given about the proposal, or any possible proposal, to pay such costs. We want to know what advice or communications on the proposal, or any possible proposal, the government received, and from what sources outside government, including private lawyers and legal firms. They are matters of particular interest. I do not mean that these are matters of passing interest such as ones that the public are interested in; these are matters of public interest. The government explaining how this decision came about is a genuine question of public interest.

Turning to term (c) of the terms of reference to be sent to this committee, we want to know what advice, from within or outside the government, was given, and what decisions were taken in respect of the fact that Dr Lawrence did not appear to have legal standing to run this matter on her own. If she did, why is she not doing so? Why does the matter appear as `Halden and Marks' in all the listings, and why is Mr Halden saying, `Well, hell; I'm not really interested in one of the aspects, but I am interested in the other—that is, cabinet confidentiality and parliamentary privilege—so, provided it will cost me nothing, yes, I have told them I'll be in it.' We want to know who `them' refers to. Who is it that he is referring to? Who enticed him into issuing these proceedings by indicating that there would be no money that he would have to pay?

Moving further on, and perhaps closer to the taxpayers' interests, we want to know what advice government had and what consideration cabinet gave to the costs that would be involved in this. We want to know what estimate there was of the likely total financial liability of the Commonwealth. Or, simply, was a blank cheque written? Was Dr Lawrence told to spend whatever it takes, whatever it costs—spend that and not a dollar or a penny less? Was any cap or limit placed on the expenditure? Was there a point at which the expenditure would be reviewed—$100,000, $200,000 or $300,000 of taxpayers' money? How much of that could be spent before there had to be some review, or was this simply a carte blanche blank cheque—`Spend what you want'? What procedures were put in place to monitor the nature and growth of the Commonwealth's financial liability with respect to this matter? These are important matters that need to be addressed.

I now move to another matter, and this is certainly not the last one. Bearing in mind that the government was funding the legal challenges from public funds, that is, from hard-earned taxpayers' money, what role did government play in relation to any of the legal challenges to the Marks royal commission, including in relation to the decisions to challenge or to appeal against lost challenges, and in relation to the nature of the arguments to be put to the respective courts on behalf of Dr Lawrence or any other person? Presumably this would allow questions to be asked about the contribution from the Attorney-General's Department. Just how much advice has flowed freely from the Attorney-General's Department to the office of the Attorney-General, and how much of that has flowed either directly or indirectly to Dr Lawrence, such that her costs need not be inflated any more than they otherwise would be? How much marrying together has there been with this convenient intervention by the Commonwealth in Dr Lawrence's proceedings? Does that mean that she and Mr Halden have free and almost complete access to the legal advice being offered by the Attorney-General's Department? These are matters that we think it is perfectly fair and reasonable to have honestly answered.

I come back to my original point. If the Commonwealth government had chosen to respond properly to the Senate's return to order, these matters could have been answered. Since the reply was, `No, you come and fight for what you want', that is what the Senate is prepared to do. No doubt we will probably have further fights about it. Hopefully, out of this tawdry mess—and I think it is a tawdry mess when the government agrees to fund a minister's private legal costs in order to scuttle a properly established royal commission, an executive act by another parliament in this nation—will come something positive. The matter was raised with me by both the Australian Democrats and the Greens and readily acceded to by us—that is, what guidelines and conditions should be put in place to ensure the legality and propriety of any use of public funds to pay the legal costs of ministers and members of parliament.

It is abundantly clear that the current guidelines are inadequate. The government is waving around the guidelines saying, `The guidelines don't refer to royal commissions; therefore we can pay. We can do what we like because we are not restricted by these guidelines.' I think that is a rubbish argument. I would say, `The fact that you are not covered by the guidelines probably means that you can't pay.' Why does the government assume that, because the guidelines do not mention royal commissions, it is entitled to spend on what it wants. For example, the guidelines do not mention legal costs relating to some other sort of civil proceeding. There must be a list of them that could be drummed up that are not mentioned in those guidelines. Do we automatically assume, therefore, that we can pay? No, we do not.

I would say that the payment is outside the guidelines. That may not make it illegal, but it certainly questions the propriety of it. But that is another matter. At least we would agree that, since royal commissions are not mentioned in the guidelines, the guidelines are inadequate in one way or another because they have led to some dispute. We could be focusing on more important things like the constitutionality and legality of the payment as opposed to whether it is within the guidelines or not. That issue at least needs to be looked at.

The second matter which was raised with me by the Greens and which I think was endorsed by the Australian Democrats was the question of the appropriate level of reporting to parliament on the use of public funds to pay the legal costs of ministers and members of parliament, including the reasons for the decision to provide such funds. There is concern right around the chamber, until you reach the Labor Party—and I suspect privately there is concern way past the line where the Labor Party starts—as to exactly what parliament ought to be told. No-one disputes that there are some matters that are appropriate to be withheld, but no-one believes that it is appropriate for government simply to make a decision and then say to parliament, `The only answers we need give you are a few press releases and we will leave it at that.' That is quite clearly inadequate. As I draw to a close, much, I imagine, to the minister's relief—

TALK.START.PARA: —He is so gracious! So gracious he is, Madam Acting Deputy President.
—Would you address the chair, Senator Vanstone.

—On your previous occasions as well.
—He is so gracious, and always is. I suspect that people on the receiving end of telephones and ashtrays do not feel that way, but I am sure you understand what I mean, Madam Acting Deputy President.

—Only if I am not provoked, Madam Acting Deputy President. I want to highlight why I think there is such concern in the community about this issue. There is concern for two reasons. First, the community understands that just because you are in government you cannot spend money on anything you like. You cannot just say, `This is inconvenient, we want to spend money on this,' especially when you end up spending the money at an estimated rate of $10,000 a day—although we still do not know that because we have not had the privilege of having the return to order satisfied. The community is very suspicious of executive action that protects one of their own—one could draw a bow not much longer than that and say executive action that protects themselves.

PARA.TAB: Quite clearly, in a pre-election environment, if you are sitting around at a table of cabinet ministers and one of them is under attack, that is very inconvenient. The easiest way to stop yourself being damaged by allowing that minister to be damaged is to step in and protect the minister. It is fine to do that in a sense of comradery, to all stand behind the person under attack in the media and in this place. You should work together as a team, but we are questioning whether you can say, `We will open the taxpayers' till, put our hand in the register and tip the money into protecting this minister.' I think you can say that each cabinet minister around that table, except any who may be leaving at the next election—by choice, that is, as opposed to being kicked out, and hopefully some of them will be—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, get on with it.
—I am getting on with it at the pace I choose. We have to listen to you—
—Order! Just ignore all interjections.
—With respect, Madam Acting Deputy President, we have to listen to him drone on ad infinitum, day after day with his overconfident delivery.
—Senator Vanstone, all interjections are out of order. Would you please ignore them.

—He always claims to possess the truth. His favourite saying is `the truth of the matter is'. He prefaces every one of his phrases with that, as though he owns what the truth is. We are sick to death of listening to him drone on and then interrupt everybody else. That is the truth of the matter.

PARA.TAB: As I was saying, one of the reasons the community is concerned is that they smell a problem here. They see money being tipped into Labor interests, they see cabinet ministers voting for something that directly benefits one of theirs and indirectly benefits all of them, and they are very suspicious about it. Senator Spindler, who has an interest in this matter, has served with me on the costs of justice committee. We all understand what limited access Australians have to the legal system when they are under attack. When the executive of this government makes a decision that impinges on the liberty of a citizen in one way or another, does the executive vote to fund that citizen's legal cost to challenge that decision? No. Why do you suppose it does not do that? Because it does not have an interest in doing so.

If I am judged against by the Social Security Tribunal or whomever, will the government fund me to take it all the way to the High Court? Will I be able to confidently walk out as Dr Lawrence did and say, `We'll take this all the way to the High Court, I am a fighter,' or will I have to sell my home, my car and lose my job in order to do so? That is what is aggravating Australian citizens. In funding a legal action, Dr Lawrence is getting Rolls Royce treatment when most Australians citizens cannot afford to get a foot in the court. She is given a blank cheque that says, `Go all the way to the High Court and back if you like, sweetheart. We do not want to see you bite the chop.' Citizens are annoyed about that.

If you have a look at the legal aid figures, you will see that less than two per cent of Australians who get legal aid—and some of this is to challenge Commonwealth executive action—get more than $10,000. It is actually less than two per cent, but I will say two per cent for convenience. So Dr Lawrence is in the top bracket. Ninety-eight per cent of Australians have not got a stone's throw in hell's chance of getting $10,000 in legal aid. Yet we have estimates that this is what Dr Lawrence is getting every day. But the figures get worse than that, much worse.

If you assume that Dr Lawrence has had at least 10 days at $10,000, you might ask how many legal aid applicants would get $100,000. It is 23 out of 130,000 approved applicants—that is less than one-tenth of one per cent—who receive this kind of treatment. They probably do not get this kind of treatment. In their case, that $100,000 would be at legal aid rates. I think it is London to a brick that Roger Gyles QC is not acting for Dr Lawrence on legal aid rates. They are the two reasons that the community is concerned. First, they smell a rat. What is going on here is that these guys have voted to protect one of their own; they have cast votes that will assist their political party. They want to keep this woman from being damaged, which of course has the ludicrous assumption in it that the minister must be making that there is damage to be done. Second, the public say they as normal citizens cannot access the courts yet she has been given Rolls Royce treatment.

I have just had a quick look through the release of 20 June 1995 put out by the Attorney-General, who I notice, in his usual courageous way, since this decision has gone sour, has gone to ground in his marginal seat. You would think Michael Lavarch had never touched this decision, that he had never put out this release on 20 June. While there are many things about you that I do not admire, Senator Evans, at least you are not a gutless wimp. Through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, we have to at least admire the Minister for Foreign Affairs because he is not a gutless wimp. He is not running to ground like the Attorney-General. He is prepared to defend his government's decision. He and the Prime Minister are prepared to do that. Michael Lavarch, the Attorney-General, the man responsible for this, the man who has the carriage of the funding of this matter, this Rolls Royce treatment for Dr Lawrence, is nowhere to be seen.

The children of Australia are probably running around saying, `Come out, come out, wherever you are,' because the boy Attorney-General has gone into hiding on this matter. Having had a quick look through his press release I do not see anything that says it is Mr Halden who is running these matters. It implies, I think, that Dr Lawrence can challenge this matter in her own right. If the Attorney-General did know at the time of putting out this press release that Dr Lawrence did not have standing in her own right, this press release is saying a lot more about the Attorney than we think. For those reasons, I urge senators to support the reference of this matter to the Senate committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government accepts that there are a number of legitimate questions of accountability in relation to the expenditure of public funds that are involved in this matter. We have no wish, as a government, to duck any questions in this respect, questions of the kind that have traditionally been asked and answered in Senate committees. We do, nonetheless, oppose this inquiry, not because there is anything we want to hide or conceal but because the issues involved here are so straightforward. PARA.TAB: We are perfectly willing to put on the record through any avenue you choose to ask us—private briefings, questions in the parliament, requests for statements or whatever—exactly the basis on which the government has acted here. I have done something in that respect in responses at question time. You mentioned a failure to take advantage of an earlier opportunity to do that in response to your return to order motion of 28 June. It will be recalled that that return to order did not ask particular questions about sequences of events or anything else; it was simply a large scale fishing expedition seeking the tabling of a mass of papers, including legal advices and other kinds of material of a kind which it is manifestly inappropriate for any government to produce—and which no government could reasonably be expected to produce.

On the substantive issues which are raised in this motion, the government is perfectly willing to address them. I want to take a little time now, if Senator Vanstone will do me the courtesy of listening since I sat here listening to her for the last half hour, to explain why this inquiry is unnecessary. I am perfectly prepared now to spell out all the basic matters that are here in issue, to the extent that it is possible for me to do it in the time available.

Let me begin with the legal basis for the decision and the sequence of events associated with that. At the starting point it is necessary for me to say that it is our judgment that the royal commission was established as a very deliberate political device to destroy Dr Lawrence's career as a Commonwealth minister; to undermine and, if possible, destroy her capacity to carry out her ministerial functions. She is entitled to defend herself from such a blatantly political attack.

I do not stop to go into all the reasons why we make that particular judgment but one of the obvious ones is that the Western Australian parliament has explored the issues associated with the tabling of this petition in its own select privileges committee inquiry set up in November 1992. It has made certain findings about the way that matter was handled. None of those go to the impropriety—or, certainly, illegality—of the tabling of the petition by Mr Halden, although issues did arise about the role in the whole affair that was played by Mr Easton.

There has been ample opportunity over the last three years—if there are issues going to the heart and soul of good government in Western Australia—for these matters to have been pursued. But, of course, the reason for their being pursued now is self-evident and we have pointed it out on innumerable occasions. I do not stop to do so now.

Confronted with an attack of this kind, any minister is entitled to defend himself or herself by all reasonable available means, including not only appearance in the commission but whatever collateral action is reasonably appropriate to tackle what are argued by the body in question to be exercises of impropriety or action beyond jurisdiction. That has been the case in the past, where people on the receiving end of these sorts of assaults have never hesitated to take that action. That was so, for example, as we have said a number of times, in relation to Mr Greiner's collateral legal attack on ICAC in New South Wales and Mr Gray's collateral attack on the Rouse royal commission in Tasmania. Both those attacks were funded by the host government, the government establishing the royal commission in question.

As to the basic position on funding, the Commonwealth government's view has been all along—and remains—that the primary responsibility for bearing those funding costs, both before the commission and in terms of reasonably based collateral attacks on it, is that of the Western Australian government. That has been a responsibility accepted by governments establishing royal commissions in the past. This one should be regarded as no exception. It was the responsibility accepted in both the Greiner and the Gray cases by governments then; and we have argued that that position should be adopted by the Western Australian government.

Dr Lawrence has written to the Western Australian government on two occasions: on 18 May and, in a more detailed submission on 4 August, concerning funding for her legal expenses arising from the royal commission, both in relation to appearances before the commission and also these collateral proceedings. She has yet to get any definitive response covering all that.

There have been some suggestions that the costs before the commission will be borne subject perhaps to unresolved issues about interstate counsel and so on. But, certainly, there has been nothing yet to suggest that the costs will be borne for the actions taken and which may still be taken in the Supreme Court and the High Court as this matter further proceeds. Anticipating, as we did as a Commonwealth government, that the Western Australian government might not honour its obligations in this matter—they had done so little else that was decent politically or morally that it was a reasonable assumption—we considered at the outset of this matter the question of paying any funds which were necessary for a legal defence and which were not picked up by the Western Australian government. Dr Lawrence, obviously, had a very great interest in what our position on this would be.

Let me explain for Senator Vanstone's information—and that of anyone else who is interested and who is prepared to listen—the legal basis on which we approached this question of funding. When the matter first came before the cabinet on 8 June, the government had before it the product of consultations on the legal questions involved between the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Finance.

In effect, those consultations had identified for cabinet's consideration two alternative and obviously available funding avenues, both of which were thought in the departmental advice concerned to be perfectly legal and perfectly proper. One was an act of grace payment under section 34A of the Audit Act. The alternative route was a straightforward single line appropriation, in the next round of appropriation bills, which would cover the payment in question.

Both of these avenues were thought to be technically inappropriate. The difficulty about the act of grace payment under section 34A was that by legislation it was solely a matter for the Minister for Finance. The cabinet had no authority or capacity to direct him in the exercise of his judgment on this matter. It was thought that for an issue of this magnitude needing the transparency of process that it undoubtedly would need when attacked—as undoubtedly it would be in the public domain—it would be better for the decision to be taken by the cabinet as a whole as an exercise of collective responsibility. That was the primary consideration in the government's mind: to do it on that basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Halden's action is a civil action.

—I will come to all that. But it is not the defence of legal proceedings; it was the initiation of legal proceedings, if you like, in the context of the collateral legal attacks on the commission. The proceedings before the royal commission itself are not to be regarded as legal proceedings for the purposes of these guidelines, particularly when you look at them and see the context in which they are written.

PARA.TAB: So we treated this, as it is appropriate to do, as essentially an ad hoc matter to be determined on a case by case basis, as indeed many of these things have been determined in the past. We decided to go straightforwardly down the route of a single line appropriation. There was never any question of any secrecy attached to this. If anyone had asked us—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, why didn't you comply with the return to order?

—Because what you did not ask us in the return to order was a set of straightforward questions; you just wanted bits and pieces of documentation laid out across the landscape for you to burrow through and make your own decision about it. If you had asked us the question, you would have got the answer. As soon as you did ask the question, you got an answer from me a few days ago in the parliament. You are getting a more detailed answer now. You will get a more detailed answer still before the inquiry from me and others when we get to it. But let me get on with it.
—Always grudging through clenched teeth.

—Look, I am being a model of sweet reason at the moment, despite the provocation, and I intend to remain so. I am explaining what happened. What happened after that was that the question was raised in public debate as to what the impact was on proceedings of this kind of section 48 of the Australian Constitution, which on its face did not have much to do with anything but did say:

SPEECH.PARA: Until the parliament otherwise provides, each senator and each member of the House of Representatives shall receive an allowance of #400 a year to be reckoned from the day on which he takes his seat.

There had been an interpretation in the case of Brown v. West in the late 1980s suggesting that that meant that any payment made to a member of parliament or, by extension, a minister that did not have the cover of some quite explicit legislative authority might run foul of that particular provision. So when that question was raised, as it was in the public domain, the question was further looked at by our legal advisers. When it was looked at, the view was taken that there was no difficulty at all if the payment was made after the one-line appropriation had, in fact, been enacted by the parliament because there would be ample legislative foundation then on which to build to satisfy section 48.

PARA.TAB: But if, as was reasonable in all the circumstances, to pay the lawyers before next April, May, June or whenever the appropriation is passed, given that expenses are being incurred, and if money was to be paid under the Advance to the Minister for Finance, then there might conceivably be, prima facie, a problem with section 48. However, on closer inspection that problem disappeared because the Parliamentary Entitlements Act 1990, which was passed explicitly in order to pick up the pieces after the Brown v. West case and to give formal legislative authority for a whole different series of payments to ministers and members, did contain an explicit provision in it which manifestly gave the legislative authority for this class of payment. Section 4(4)(b) of the Parliamentary Entitlements Act, which refers to—let me put it on the record—`benefits afforded by the government to a minister for the purpose of carrying out functions of the minister' is the basis on which the government decided, after looking at it again with the benefit of further legal advice, was a perfectly sound basis on which to proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you tell us what section of the constitution the Parliamentary Entitlements Act relies on and is therefore limited to?

—The Parliamentary Entitlements Act is primarily an exercise in legislation under section 48 of the constitution. There may well be some other support that can be derived from it, which I do not stop to explore now, but from the point of view of seeing what the parliament did in order to cope with the possible consequences of the Brown v. West case, that was it and the clear head of legislative authority was there.

PARA.TAB: Of course, that legislative authority does not authorise the payment of particular dollars and cents; that still has to be done by way of a parliamentary appropriation. All I am saying is that what happened, if you look at the sequence of events here, is that the Solicitor-General came into the issue at this point—he had not been involved before on these funding questions—and he gave some oral advice to the government. When the issue became one in the public domain and people wanted to know the legal basis on which the government had acted, it was at that point that the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) asked the Solicitor-General to explain for the purposes of public presentation—because there is a legitimate matter of public interest here involved—the nature of the legal reasoning that was here involved.

There is one further point to be made about all of this in terms of the Commonwealth's interest in this matter, and that is that the terms of the royal commission are such that issues of parliamentary privilege, and indeed cabinet confidentiality, will inevitably arise. That has become extremely obvious with the proceedings of the commission as they have worked themselves out. That involves, of course, real questions in which the Commonwealth, just as much as any state government, has an interest because they go to the heart of the effective operation of the Westminster system. So it goes to much more than any defence of a defamation proceeding or of the kind that has been regularly funded by governments for ministers of all parties over the years on your side of politics just as much as ours.

Much more than that, this particular action against Dr Lawrence did not just go to her pocketbook but to her very capacity to perform her functions as a minister. The kinds of issues that have arisen in the course of the proceedings so far and that are manifestly interconnected with it go squarely to the heart of her capacity to perform her public office, both as a member of parliament and as a minister. So that is an additional reinforcement for the argument that 4(4)(b) of the Parliamentary Entitlements Act is the appropriate basis on which to proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think a year-12 legal studies student would believe that.

—Beyond that, so far as the question of advice is concerned—because the inquiry as proposed wants to wander at large over the advice given—I can only say here what was said by Senator Bolkus in the Senate on 29 June, when he tabled some documents in response to a return to order. The government simply does not make available government documents which fall within accepted boundaries of legal professional privilege and public interest immunity to the Senate. We certainly will not be doing that to a Senate committee. Nor is it the practice or has it been the practice over the years for any government to make available legal advice from its legal advisers made in the course of the normal decision making process of government, for good practical reasons associated with good government and also as a matter of fundamental principle.

PARA.TAB: The same applies to material prepared for and considered by cabinet and any records of the discussion or outcomes of that consideration. The significance of cabinet confidentiality in this respect has been amply acknowledged by all sorts of people over the years, most recently by Richard Court himself in Western Australia, which I think is worth while acknowledging at this point for the public record. This is a submission made by the Western Australian government to the Western Australian commission on government in April this year under a covering letter from the premier:

SPEECH.PARA: Secrecy of cabinet proceedings is fundamental to underpinning the doctrines of cabinet solidarity and collective responsibility under which all ministers, irrespective of their individual views, are required to support cabinet decisions outside the cabinet room, particularly in parliament. Without this secrecy, cabinet collective responsibility would be impossible to uphold. . . For collective responsibility to work, members of cabinet should be able to express views openly and frankly. In the deliberation of matters before cabinet if confidentiality does not attach to such discussions the quality of the debate in cabinet and the consequent decisions will be adversely affected. . . It is significant that the principle of cabinet confidentiality has been maintained since the inception of the cabinet system of government. It is considered that it is in the public interest to retain that existing level of confidentiality.

It would be quite useful if people thought a little bit more about the implications of what they say before acting in manifest breach of their own stated principles. These are the principles on which the government will be relying in its approach to this.

PARA.TAB: Let me now come to the question of standing, which occupies so much of Senator Vanstone's waking hours on this particular subject. Contrary to media reports and her own suggestions in this place, Dr Lawrence is and has been at all times a party in her own right to the proceedings both before the Western Australian Supreme Court and the High Court. Reports in the press that her name is not listed in the court challenges is just plain wrong. Laura Tingle's report was plain wrong. She is, in fact, listed as the second applicant, the second plaintiff. No challenge was made to Dr Lawrence's standing before the courts at any stage of the proceedings which have been carried out so far. That is consistent with the fact that is blindingly obvious to everyone—except, apparently, Senator Vanstone—that the mere fact that she is not mentioned in the terms of reference does not derogate from the fact that she is the primary target of the commission; she has an obvious interest and obvious standing.

It was a matter for Dr Lawrence and her legal advisers to be fully comfortable and confident about that question. Right back at the beginning when her name was not in the terms of reference, when she had not been called as a witness, when she had not been associated with the original petition, there was some concern on the part of some of her advisers that a court might be inclined to deny her standing. Might I say that was never my view. I do not think it was the view of the Solicitor-General and I do not think it was the view of a lot of others. But through an abundance of caution Dr Lawrence and her advisers sought the reinforcement of participation in those proceedings from Mr Halden.

The fact that Mr Halden is also involved in that legal challenge has never been a secret. Nobody has sought to hide the fact. There is absolutely nothing colourable about that. Parties are joined all the time in these sorts of proceedings to enable them to get off the ground or to enable them, as in this case, to get off the ground with perhaps just an extra layer of confidence.

What is important, however, is that the Commonwealth government's funding decision, if it becomes necessary for us to pay anything, relates solely to Dr Lawrence's costs, not to costs referrable to any other party in this case. The Australian Government Solicitor, I am able to say to the Senate, wrote to Mr Halden's solicitors on 19 July asking that all legal expenses in relation to their representation of Mr Halden which do not relate to Dr Lawrence be separately itemised. Moreover, all bills submitted to Dr Lawrence will be carefully scrutinised to ensure that the government is not, under any circumstances, meeting his expenses. Any arrangements which Mr Halden and his solicitors might make in relation to his representation are purely a matter for him. We have not been a party to those arrangements.

A question did arise—just for completeness, since your terms of reference refer to standing of any other party—about the question of whether the Commonwealth Attorney-General had standing himself to initiate these proceedings. I do not think anyone seriously thought there was a basis on which he could have initiated those proceedings himself, as they were a challenge then at that stage to the Western Australian royal commission. However, there is, unquestionably, an opportunity for the Commonwealth Attorney-General to intervene if and when the substantive matters in issue are dealt with by the High Court.

Once a matter raising questions of parliamentary privilege, cabinet confidentiality and the law relating to that gets up to the High Court, obviously it is a potentially binding impact and authority on the Commonwealth government as well as then any particular state. Obviously, the Commonwealth has a major interest, and certainly it could be expected that, if the matter does arise substantively in this way, the Attorney-General will seek leave to claim the right to intervene. There is no doubt about his capacity to do that. But that question has not arisen yet.

As to the quantum of costs involved in this, Senator Vanstone—if you are interested; you keep chatting away about everything under the sun to your neighbours and do not listen to the substantive issues involved here—in accordance with longstanding established practice, no claims will be made unless claims of payment have been certified by the Australian Government Solicitor as fair and reasonable having regard to reasonable commercial practice. There is no blank cheque to pursue any legal avenue, no matter how unwarranted that particular avenue might be.

All bills that are rendered by Dr Lawrence's solicitors will be closely scrutinised by officers within the Office of the AGS, taking into account factors such as the overall amount of the account, the nature of the work done, the size and experience of the legal team, hourly rates charged by the solicitors and the overall importance and complexity of the issues involved. Of course, examination of any payments made by the Commonwealth is open to the Auditor-General for scrutiny as part of the normal audit process.

At this stage of the proceedings, it is simply not possible to be definitive about the amounts likely to be involved—not least because we have not yet heard from the Western Australian government definitively as to what proportion of the costs, if any, they are prepared to pick up. There is no indication of how long the commission will run—it could be a matter of days or weeks or months—and any estimate would necessarily be so much a guess at this stage as to be totally misleading.

As to the role of the Commonwealth and the conduct of this litigation, Dr Lawrence has been represented before the commission, and in the Western Australian Supreme Court and the High Court, by counsel engaged by her through solicitors appointed by her. It has not been a matter for the Commonwealth to try to influence her choice of solicitor. In cases of a comparable kind—defamation proceedings and so on—over the years, it has always been regarded as a matter for the individual minister or member of parliament being assisted to make their own particular choice.

TALK.START.PARA: —If this is Commonwealth interest, the government solicitor should be doing it.

—It may be that if the Attorney-General was to intervene it would be thought to be inappropriate for the Attorney-General to, in effect, be briefed by the same—if he is intervening rather than actually participating as a party to the case—firm of solicitors, in effect the Australian Government Solicitor. But one way or the other—I do not make a final judgment about that—the point is that it is entirely consistent with previous precedent and practice for the thing to be done in this way.

PARA.TAB: Let me finally say something about the government's approach to the conduct of this inquiry. We do not concede that it is necessary. We do not concede that any further useful information of a kind that I have not already briefly summarised here, which I am happy to supplement at some later stage if you want me to in lieu of going down the inquiry route, could emerge. We do not concede that the inquiry is in any way necessary. However, it is obvious looking around the chamber that you do have the numbers to insist upon an inquiry. If you do, what is the approach we are going to take?

Consistent with the approach I have adopted standing here today, and in answers to these sorts of questions in the parliament hitherto, I can say to you that the government will cooperate with the inquiry, subject only to the normal limits that have been imposed in the past, and which we will want to insist upon, relating to various specific matters which I will retail.

It is proposed that, in relation to the government's involvement, in the first instance I will appear before the committee of inquiry to answer questions from the committee relating to the government's decision, questions of policy and anything that might be involved in relation to that. Secondly, we think it would be appropriate to make available the Solicitor-General, Dr Gavan Griffith, to appear before the inquiry, to place no barriers in his path, for him to explain—to the extent it needs explanation; it is pretty straightforward—the legal opinion that he has given specifically at the request of—

TALK.START.PARA: —Straightforwardly doubtful.

—You can have your day of arguing that out with him. We are not in any way going to create any difficulties in that respect. Thirdly, we do think it would be appropriate for you to—Senator Vanstone, if you are going to listen, please do. You are really very rude standing there nattering away. I know Senator Newman is a fascinating conversationalist, but you have hardly listened to a word I have been saying for the last 25 minutes.
—I am capable of listening while I am talking.
—It is extremely rude in most parts of the universe when somebody is talking to you, seeking to respond to specific questions you have asked, to not listen while the response is given.
—You are not talking to me. You are talking to Madam Deputy Chair. You are not meant to be talking to me.

—I will go on to say that in addition to me and the Solicitor-General, we think it appropriate that you should have available a senior member of the Attorney-General's Department, obviously someone in the area of the Australian Government Solicitor, who will have the conduct and management of the handling of this matter, is familiar with it and can tell you about the process and procedure so far as a fair and reasonable evaluation of that criteria is concerned.

PARA.TAB: Fourthly, we think it appropriate that you should have a senior officer of the Department of Finance available to answer questions about the way in which Finance processes operate, precedents that have applied in this particular area and the way in which the appropriation system and related matters work. I think access to senior officers from the Attorney-General's Department, Finance, the Solicitor-General and the minister is a pretty reasonable demonstration of the government's willingness to cooperate.

The only limits that we will set—and that is consistent with what is done in all these committees—are: firstly, questions going to policy matters will be for me to answer, not officials; and, secondly, we are not prepared, as I have already indicated, to make available legal advice prepared in the ordinary course for the purpose of the development of government policy or the making of specific government decisions. The confidential relationship between the government's legal advisers is an essential part of the business of government.

From time to time, as was the case here, we do make specific legal material available in order to publicly explain, consistent with accountability principles, what we have done. But that is not the same as making available the particular advice, not because we have anything to hide but because we are defending a principle. The third limitation is that, in relation to advice given to cabinet, material prepared for and considered by cabinet or for ministers preparing themselves for cabinet, as well as records of cabinet discussion, remain outside the pale. That would extend to questions asked of either me or officials in the course of the hearing.

We are prepared to cooperate. Many of the questions that you have raised are perfectly legitimate ones to ask about in the public domain. Any expenditure of public money has to be justified by the executive government and has to be explained in the parliament. We fully accept that. We never had any intention of imposing any constraints on access to that kind of information.

It was quite unnecessary to go down this path. You should have asked sensible questions, instead of going on a great fishing expedition in your return to order where you are not asking for particular information; you are just asking for categories of documents to be supplied. You were only able to get access to a limited number of those documents because the production of many of them would have breached the principles to which I refer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not at all. You crossed out the relevant material.

—Same thing. I conclude by saying that we are confident about the course that the government has adopted. It is consistent with past practice and precedent. There is no question about legality; there is no question about propriety.

PARA.TAB: The only thing that is at issue, and has been from day one, about this whole sorry and sordid affair has been the squalid political motivation of those who have been running it. You will not get any of that in response from this particular government. We will behave as we always do, as an honest and responsible government prepared to be fully accountable to the public for any money that we spend.

TALK.START.PARA: —As previous speakers have said, a number of question marks arise from and hang over what I too will call a messy issue. For the Australian Democrats some of those include: the motivation of the Western Australian government in setting up the royal commission and its terms of reference; equally important, the legal basis of the government's decision to fund the legal expenses of Dr Lawrence; and how past parliamentary actions in one parliament legally impact on present parliamentary functions in another parliament—one of the unique aspects of this particular case.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats asked the government to give a detailed public statement on the legal basis of the funding and Senator Gareth Evans did that last week. On further scrutiny of that statement we felt that one or two areas required some further probing, some fleshing out. Specifically, we would seek to test the legal basis of part 4 of the government's advice—performing her functions as a minister. And, secondly, once one accepts the right to challenge, as the Democrats do, we would want to ask and probe the question: is this an open-ended acceptance of process? Does that mean that, with challenge and counter-challenge and backwards and forwards in jurisdictions, the government accepted that it would fund those without a cap indefinitely? I think those are legitimate questions. However, the Democrats did not feel, important though this is, that it warranted the expense of a Senate select committee at that time. It would be ironic if we ended up spending as much money on a Senate committee as the issue that we were inquiring into.

TALK.START.PARA: —We probably will, knowing the record of this place.

—We will not be doing that now, Senator Sherry. The Democrats felt it was more appropriate to refer the matter to the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee. We thought that that had a good record on inquiring into matters like this. For example, it has already looked at: the legality of sacking Justice Staples from the Industrial Relations Commission; the legal extent of the external affairs power; the legal protection needed for the Sydney Olympics marketing; et cetera, et cetera. The opposition has agreed with that request.

PARA.TAB: We have always said too on the record that any select committee should include a focus on future policy, for example, the appropriateness of the guidelines and the appropriate transparency requirements in place to account for the use of public funds. It is equally important to have this particular committee, although it is not a select committee, look into that as well. So we accept the new parts 2(f) and 2(g).

The Democrats asked for different reporting dates for the two parts of the reference, firstly, because we think that the new parts of the reference—2(f) and 2(g)—will need a greater time for consideration with respect to reporting. Because we do need to take our time on future policy implications without seeking to delay the reporting on the issue of current process and current actions.

I stress that this committee reference and what this committee will be doing is not about whether Dr Carmen Lawrence did or did not mislead the Western Australian parliament. But it is about a number of important principles, which I think it is important for us to actually spend more time looking at—principles such as: the whole nature of the appropriateness of process for granting payment for legal expenses of a minister and, as I said, the uniqueness of Dr Lawrence's situation; an individual's right to challenge the legitimacy of a body conducting an inquiry; and cabinet confidentiality for all governments.

In the committee, too, the Democrats intend to ask questions about the responsibilities of governments in setting up royal commissions, including responsibilities for funding. Without reflecting on any royal commission currently in progress—and there are some—I make the point that royal commissions are a very important part of the checks and balances of our democratic processes. In our committee inquiry we must also ensure that the public does not have a reason to lose faith in the objectivity of royal commissions. The Democrats support this reference to the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The extreme irony of the Marks royal commission is that it is on the use of executive power. The Greens (WA) believe that Premier Court's motives in instituting a royal commission may well be criticised as political and can also be argued to constitute an abuse of power as premier for political reasons, or as a vendetta for the personal accusations directed towards him in the Easton petition.

PARA.TAB: However, one wrong does not justify a further wrong. The federal government's decision to fund Dr Lawrence's legal costs can also be argued to be a political exercise and an abuse of power. The question may well be asked whether this royal commission would have been mounted if Dr Lawrence were an ordinary member of the community. It has been asked and we know it has been asked several times. It may equally be asked whether she would have taxpayer funding for her legal costs if she were an ordinary community member.

I believe that the government has a case to answer, because at least the royal commission was set up legally and the jury is definitely out on whether the federal government has acted legally. From the Western Australian perspective, what has occurred looks disturbingly like and very little different from a painful history of the Australian Labor Party using its power and access to public funds to protect itself and its mates from the consequences of its activities both within government and within business. So it is for that reason that we believe there is a case to answer by the government on whether it has fulfilled, or can answer properly four questions about the federal funding of Dr Lawrence's legal challenge to the state government appointed royal commission.

Those four questions are: firstly, is there any precedent for this? We believe the answer is no. Senator Gareth Evans has argued two precedents which we believe are inappropriate: those of the Greiner situation where state funding was used to challenge a state commission; and the Rouse or Gray situation where state government funding, again, was to a state commission and the payment was done well after the event and only for one of the parties and was a highly controversial decision. So there is no precedent in our view, and that question still deserves an inquiry.

Secondly, does it fit existing guidelines? The answer is clearly no. Senator Evans implied from that that it was a kind of oversight that it does not fit existing guidelines. The only point I would want to make here is that it was never envisaged that it should fit and that is why it is not mentioned. So there is a clear duty to look at why the guidelines have not covered this particular instance and not simply assume that it was an oversight.

The third point concerns legality. As I have mentioned before, the jury is still out on that. It is quite clear that, when the government provided its final explanation on the legality of it, it was an after-the-fact explanation. It was required eight weeks ago when it initially announced the decision about the clear legal basis for providing that funding. Despite eight weeks of public debate and days of debate in the parliament on the matter, the government has still failed to give good reasons for providing the funding for Dr Lawrence's legal costs.

It has only bothered to come up with a legal reason for the decision after the event and after the question was raised about the constitutionality of the whole basis of making those funds available. When the government makes controversial decisions of this kind, it clearly should provide full reasons at the time it makes those decisions and not because they have been repeatedly challenged.

The fourth question which the government needs to answer is whether it is proper that such a decision has been made. I believe that there are serious questions about that because of the question of illegality, because it has not fitted the guidelines and because it is an unprecedented decision and action. Full justification has not been made available to the parliament and, therefore, the people of Australia. There is the persistent refusal of cabinet to accept, in its need for that kind of accountability, that there are questions over the propriety of it. In our view, there is doubt in all of these four areas. That is the basis of our support for this inquiry.

The fact is that none of the precedents cited by the government fit the situation. The guidelines for providing ministers with legal aid do not fit. The legal argument the government is using is, at best, flimsy and, at worst, a clear indication that the government does not have the power to make the decision in the way that it has. Unfortunately, that flimsy legal power to pay Dr Lawrence's bill would evaporate if she were to resign. They have ultimately found under section 4(4)(b) that they are entitled to provide this legal funding. The problem is that they are using this section of the parliamentary entitlements legislation as a catch-all. It is quite clear that the government has not been provided with that section in order to have unfettered power and not be challenged. So it is being challenged, and quite appropriately.

One could argue that, if having a house in Yarralumla helps a minister to carry out his or her duties, it should be covered by section 4(4)(b). There are many other interesting accoutrements of political survival or of even simply being a member of parliament in this place that could be argued to fit under this clause if you use the kind of loose and slapdash interpretation that Senator Evans has and which the Solicitor-General appears to have provided as the only basis for providing funding for the health minister's challenge to the royal commission.

I believe that there is a serious matter here. It puts her in a situation involving a conflict of interest and the invidious situation where she is likely to lose an enormous amount of money if she does resign and then loses the tenuous legal argument which the government has cited as its main basis for providing that funding.

The Greens have agreed to refer the matter to the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

SPEECH.PARA: From the start, I would like to thank the Democrats as this is in fact a shared motion. It is shared because of its importance, urgency and timing today in relation to this week's focus on the need for governments all around the world to take urgent action in relation to banning forever the production, transfer, sale, export, stockpiling or use of antipersonnel mines. There are a number of issues which I would like to address today but mainly I will deal with why the government's response to this issue has been inadequate, why there is a need to implement a total ban and why the government is not fulfilling what the majority of the community is asking for.

PARA.TAB: First of all, I would like to remind the Senate of the answers that were given to me by Senator Gareth Evans in response to my questions about the legality of landmines, and why the Australian government was not taking a stronger stand in relation to them. Senator Evans responded that basically I was being hopelessly utopian in requesting that the Australian government take a stand to call for the ban. The interesting thing is that, without a vote, the United Nations, and that includes Australia, has taken a decision which has called for the total ban of landmines. Boutros Boutros-Ghali has also called for the total ban of landmines.

I looked up the word `utopian' in the dictionary and it said `ideally perfect but impractical'. Does that mean Senator Evans is saying that what both the United Nations and, in particular, Boutros Boutros-Ghali are asking for is totally impractical? Does that mean it is never possible, not possible now, or not wanted by a number of states? One could also ask whether in this particular debate it is something that cannot be decided, that ethics on this principle cannot be decided by individual nations. I would argue that this is one area where ethics can be decided by particular nations, but there has been a decision in Australia that we will not support it.

Why is this the case? I have received letters from a number of people in the community on this issue. One of the letters I received was from the Charter 89 Society, an organisation for education and human rights with a South-East Asian focus. There were some quotes in that letter from Jane's Infantry Weapons with regard to the devices which Australia is making and selling, exporting or trying to export. In relation to fragmentation grenades that can be fitted with devices which make them usable as landmines—and Australia supplies the fitting devices—Jane's Infantry Weapons quotes the code that they are devices:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . which will allow individual modules to be adapted to special needs, giving great versatility in field conditions . . . or remote actuation, with minimum preparation or ancillary equipment . . . allows them to be easily converted to other uses in the field.

There is a definite message contained here. I have also asked the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) a number of questions with regard to landmines. The letter, quoting Jane's Infantry Weapons, continues:

The trip wire which we are selling, along with the fragmentation grenades and accessories which are an integral part of the illuminating grenade can also be provided separately and used with any grenades in the ADI system . . . the device has its own full range of accessories, including a trip wire for pull or tension release, plus pressure actuation and pressure release models.

This information is particularly interesting because I asked the Minister for Defence whether any trip wire accessory or firing device F1A1 could be fitted to any grenades in the Australian Defence Industries' system, to which the answer was yes. I then asked to which grenades in the ADI system could any trip wire accessory or firing device be fitted, and the answer was all of them. I also asked whether any of the grenades or devices could fit into the international definition of a landmine and the answer was:

No. The definition of a landmine under Article 2 of Protocol II to the 1980 Inhumane Weapons Convention is `any munition placed under, on or near the ground or other surface area and designed to be detonated or exploded by the presence, proximity or contact of a person or vehicle'.

I also looked up the definition of `trip' and found it meant `stumble, cause to stumble, make false step or mistake'. I would say it would be a very big mistake for people to stumble over, fall on or walk near any of the trip wire devices which were sold or used by Australian Defence Industries. The answer is that the Australian government does not want to take this action because we are selling devices which, under almost any definition except the pedantics of the Australian defence minister, would be considered to be a landmine. The point is that there are already protocols which make these kinds of devices illegal.

PARA.TAB: There are protocols which say that devices used in situations which are likely to have most impact on civilians are not legal. But the government is saying that this is a legitimate weapon of war and not only are we going to sell these weapons, which are aimed in nearly all cases against civilians, but we are not prepared to ask the world to ban antipersonnel landmines. We heard today that many children injured by landmines do not die straight away; they are not taken to hospital and they slowly bleed to death because nobody knows that they have been injured.

Australia is pretending that we are taking action to strengthen the protocol but we are in fact allowing exceptions through which one could drive a truck. The exceptions include such things as detectability and the mapping of landmine fields. These days nearly all landmines are spread by remote means. A lot of landmines are dropped by aeroplanes and some of them are fired out of guns. There is no ability to map landmines. But one does not have to do that because, supposedly, they explode after a certain period of time. However, the problem is that they do not always work, just as ADI bullets do not always work. Landmines work even less than ADI bullets or Steyr rifles when they overheat.

The Australian government and the Department of Defence are hiding behind semantic arguments. One could ask who is developing and pushing foreign affairs policy. It is probably the military in this particular area because the military and the Australian government are still saying that antipersonnel landmines are a legitimate weapon of war, even though they are seldom used in defence. There is very little to justify Australia using landmines as a defensive weapon.

Possibly one or two airforce bases in Australia could be landmined but that would not stop anyone landing here. There are many ways by which to enter Australia and to landmine the whole area would be impossible. The expanses over which one would be required to lay landmines would create a huge problem. That would only be done if we were already fully occupied. The reality is that Australia is never likely to be in a situation to use landmines as a defensive weapon. Therefore this last vestige of excuse has disappeared.
