TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Omit all words after ``urgency'', substitute:
``The need to implement a total ban on long-lived anti-personnel landmines and a total ban on mines which cannot be detected.
The need to restrict transfers of landmines to those countries which are state parties to the 1980 Inhumane Weapons Convention.
The need to extend the provisions of the Convention to apply to internal conflicts.
The need for more effective verification of compliance with the Convention, including through more frequent review conferences.

TAB.TAB: The development of a plan to ensure that our stocks of mines comply with the bans outlined above''.

SPEECH.PARA: There is certainly no lack of concern or compassion or deep-felt desire to see a reduction in the horrific consequences of landmines used as a weapon. In an ideal world they would be removed totally. The government is not pretending concern as Senator Margetts alleges.

PARA.TAB: I will deal with some of the points raised. We are concerned about the injuries to civilians caused by the indiscriminate use and the lingering presence of antipersonnel landmines. We do not accept that the solution to the problem caused by antipersonnel landmines is a total ban. The government is aware that the Inhumane Weapons Convention is in need of overhaul. That is why we have been working for the last two years to develop proposals to strengthen it and improve adherence to it. These proposals will be considered at the first review conference being held in Vienna from 25 September to 13 October.

Since the process of reviewing the convention began, adherence has climbed from 34 to 50 members. We expect this to increase further in the coming months. The government is doing its best to facilitate this.

There are solutions to the problem of indiscriminate use of antipersonnel landmines other than a total ban. The government approach is to support a ban on long-lived antipersonnel mines and the conversion of stockpiles to short-lived mines—that is, self-destructing, self-deactivating landmines—thereby preserving our ability to protect Australia's defence personnel in military conflicts while doing away with the lingering threat of landmines to civilians once hostilities have ceased.

Unlike the approach adopted by the drafters of this motion, the government's approach is based firmly on a responsible calculation of our national interest. It achieves a balance between our humanitarian concerns and the interests of a government to provide for Australia's security.

Our approach is also anchored in a sound assessment of what is achievable and effective. We are sympathetic to the long-term objective of eliminating antipersonnel mines. Last year we supported a UN General Assembly resolution that affirmed the ultimate goal of the eventual elimination of antipersonnel landmines as viable and humane alternatives are developed.

Nevertheless, landmines, like other conventional weapons, are at present regarded by most countries—and I emphasise most countries—as a legitimate weapon against potential enemy combat forces in times of armed conflict. The creation of an international consensus favouring a total ban is therefore not remotely in prospect at the present time. Antipersonnel mines also perform a unique military function as a remote-controlled or delayed-action weapon in the protection of Australian defence personnel and the forces of our allies in the field, including on peacekeeping missions.

The government's approach is based on several steps which will save more lives in the short to medium term than would a quixotic call for a total ban. The gravest inhumanity of anti-personnel mines is their indiscriminate effect on civilians. Our proposal, in the context of the review of the Inhumane Weapons Convention, for a ban on long-lived mines and a commitment to the use of self-destructing mines addresses this problem.

Acceptance of this proposal would represent a major step forward towards protecting civilians from the threat currently posed by mines which linger unexploded after the conclusion of hostilities. We are also proposing that the convention be extended to cover non-international conflicts. We expect this proposal to be adopted at the review conference. We are also seeking to restrict transfers of short-lived mines to countries which are parties to the convention and to develop verification mechanisms for the convention. The government believes that the foregoing proposals represent the limits of what is practical at the present time for a policy designed to confront the humanitarian challenge posed by the indiscriminate effect of antipersonnel landmines.

By way of background: on the government's count there are nine states which in principle support a total ban. They are: Austria, Belgium, Cambodia, Columbia, Estonia, Ireland, Mexico, Norway and Sweden. Of these, three—Cambodia, Columbia and Estonia—are not parties to the Inhumane Weapons Convention. None is actively campaigning for a total ban and none is a major military power. The exact position of most with regard to their stockpiles is, moreover, ambiguous. For instance, Belgium, which has been lauded for its recent comprehensive law to ban antipersonnel mines, has not taken any steps to rid itself of its stockpile.

In the past, NGOs have commonly added a further dimension to their criticism of the government's policy by emphasising that self-destructive landmines, as currently manufactured, can have a failure rate of up to 10 per cent. If true, this would be completely unacceptable to the government; but the government believes these figures are dubious. Technical advice available to the government indicates that a failure rate of the order of 0.1 per cent should be possible in mines with the self-destructive mechanism.

At the Inhumane Weapons Convention Review Conference we will argue for the lowest achievable failure rate. We will also propose that mines self-deactivate. Australia will propose that landmines must be designed to both self-destruct and, if this fails, to deactivate passively by a process of natural automatic degradation through the use of either biodegradable materials or batteries whose charge leaks away within a set period. The combination of a self-destructive mechanism with a self-deactivation feature means that the destruction of all mines is almost foolproof. These two measures together would greatly reduce the threat anti-personnel mines currently pose to civilians.

The government has asked the Department of Defence to prepare a plan to ensure that the ADF's future mine holdings can be consistent with the Australian position against long-lived undetectable landmines. Issues such as the cost and time required to replace stocks are now being examined. The restrictions on the use of landmines in the Inhumane Weapons Convention have long been incorporated into ADF doctrine and training. Australian forces thus abide by IWC rules whenever and wherever they use mines. The ADF would certainly not lay mines indiscriminately.

On the issue of the verification, some of the state parties to the convention have put forward proposals to set up mechanisms to verify compliance with the convention in relation to the use of landmines. One option is the establishment of a permanent commission of state parties which would collect information on compliance with the convention. Another proposal, co-sponsored by Australia, is to permit any state party to request the convention or a verification commission to open an inquiry into the use of mines in a particular conflict.

Antipersonnel mines result in horrendous physical injuries and carnage, often long after conflict has ended. The term `weapons of mass destruction in slow motion' has, unfortunately, been well earned. The need for the medical treatment and rehabilitation of victims places great strain on countries with severely limited resources. Mines have an effect beyond the visible and often tragic impact of human suffering. Mines also result in widespread disruption to social and economic activity. Mines restrict the productive use of arable land in war ravaged countries where the people rely heavily on agriculture for their livelihood—no better illustrated than in Cambodia. But, for the reasons outlined, we believe the proposed amendment is the most practical course to follow on this very difficult issue.

The Red Cross estimates that today there are more than 100 million unexploded landmines scattered in 62 countries, claiming an estimated 800 victims every single month. Every single landmine out there is a bad thing. Only a global ban will help to eliminate the horrors and dangers of landmine warfare and put a stop to the human suffering and social as well as economic devastation. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of this motion. I note that today is the national day of action for the group called International Campaign to Ban Landmines that is trying to urge the government to strengthen its stance on this issue. I just mention briefly the very graphic and vivid photographic exhibition entitled `A future in which civilians face death with every step' that was launched today, which illustrates the non-humanitarian aspects of anti-personnel landmines.

PARA.TAB: There were two things that struck me most clearly at the launching of that photographic exhibition. There was the mention by the member for Adelaide, Trish Worth, that in previous times 90 per cent of the casualties of war were soldiers and that, in the current era, 90 per cent are civilians, mainly women and children. The other really potent message from the photographic exhibition was delivered by Mr Rae McGrath, the Director of the Mines Advisory Group in Britain, who reminded us that the photographs were of the lucky ones—the people who were able to be rescued, who had had proper hospital care for their amputations, and who were provided with some measure of support. The unlucky ones bled to death in the fields with their sheep or with the firewood that they had been collecting. I think it is an indictment that Australia does not have a firmer stance.

We have a call from 130 community groups within Australia in this international campaign to ban landmines. It is also supported by the Secretary-General of the UN, President Clinton, the President of the International Committee of the Red Cross, UNICEF, the UNHCR, Pope John Paul II, Archbishop Desmond Tutu and the Secretary-General of the World Council of Churches, and I am sure that my colleagues have received requests for support from churches, and the heads of those churches, within Australia.

There is no doubt that the Australian government recognises the humanitarian tragedy caused by the 100 million mines scattered in over 62 countries. We have contributed towards demining efforts in Cambodia and other mine-affected countries such as Afghanistan, Mozambique and Angola. These efforts are, of course, necessary. But how does Australia look to the people of these mine-affected countries when we have direct first-hand experience of the human tragedy—the laying waste of thousands of lives—that keeps going long after the war zone is cleared of any personnel that have to do with warfare? The United Nations has shown clearly that the cost of lifetime rehabilitation for landmine victims, over 35,000 people in Cambodia, is over $3,000. That means an added $105 million in surgery and rehabilitation for a country that is struggling to survive. We cannot estimate the human and social costs of that damage, let alone of those who do not survive.

Senator Sherry has moved an amendment and we indicate that, like the Democrats, we will not be able to support the government's amendment. We will not, therefore, be able to support the watered down version of the motion that we are supporting at present if the opposition unfortunately adds its support to the government to once again push through something that represents a very weak version of what we really want. Australia's military motivation has to be questioned at this point when we fail to have anything more than a lukewarm version of what we need—a total ban.

Our fragmentation grenades with trip-wires are not self-destructive, and the government says they do not have to be because they are not classified as landmines. Australia is implicated in the military production of destructive weapons. Our whole reputation is compromised if we do not support a total ban on all landmines and urge that the Australian government stance be far stronger at the Vienna conference which is going to be held in September. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue we are facing and addressing tonight, the banning of landmines, is indeed one of the most important issues facing the world today. It is a major problem. There are estimates of up to 100 million landmines scattered worldwide. Estimates are that there are at least 20 million landmines in Angola, and that up to a third of Angola is actually unusable because of landmines. Apparently up to a million extra landmines are distributed—that is, planted—each year. In Cambodia, as a result of landmines, one in every 230 or so civilians is missing a limb, compared with, for example, in the US, one in every 22,000. Some 10,000 civilians die each year from landmines. The majority of those, disproportionately, are the innocents, the children, who are unable to understand the warnings about landmines. Another 6,000 or 7,000 are injured, usually with loss of limb, every single year. It is a major issue.

PARA.TAB: But in many ways the issue is wider than that. There are a number of areas where we need to look at issues addressing world peace. One of the things we need to bear in mind, as any humane people I think would agree, is the need for us to look at generalised issues around the world. We need to look at the extent of the possibility of world mass destruction, and all processes which limit the nature of weaponry and its wholesale impact obviously merit the strongest possible scrutiny and support.

In war, if there must be war, limitations must be made wherever possible to the main armed contenders. The protection of the civilian population deserves our strenuous endeavours. Total warfare, the blind, insensate unleashing of armed might against whole populations—children, women and the aged; unarmed, defenceless people, caught up through no fault of their own—is a greater abomination. There are lessons there from World War II. The bombing of cities in the UK and Germany in particular, Hiroshima and Nagasaki, must all cause us to look to ways in future to stop or limit the impact on non-combatants. We have had a number of conventions, notably the Geneva convention, to outlaw certain practices. Of course, we know how they failed with the Holocaust and the Japanese slaughter of millions of Chinese. Currently, too, there are episodes of racial and religious cleansing in Cambodia, Rwanda and Bosnia. There is clearly a need to achieve a reduction in weapons of mass destruction of a range of types.

There is a need to achieve eventually the total banning of the production, transfer, sale, export, stockpiling and use of antipersonnel mines—indeed, of all mine devices which are implanted in the ground to prevent human or vehicle progress over the territory. All such devices can and do wreak havoc on civilian populations. The refugee camps and hospitals of Vietnam, Cambodia, Thailand and Laos are testimony to this issue. There are thousands of men, women and, sadly, children who have suffered grave injuries and deformities from these weapons. The injuries and killings from the mines already dropped or laid will continue for many years. It is almost impossible to totally clear a known minefield. Many mined areas, as we have heard tonight, are essentially uncharted. For compassionate reasons these weapons should eventually be banned, along with chemical and biological weapons and, of course, nuclear weapons of all kinds, great and small—including the so-called theatre nuclear weapons and neutron bombs. For military reasons alone mines are unintelligent since they—like gas, for example, in World War I—deny the use of the territory to everybody for an indefinite period and may indeed turn upon the user.

The question here is what is realistically achievable. There is no immediate prospect of a worldwide agreement to a total ban, so the coalition position is to support the government's amendment because it is realistic to ban long-lived and undetectable mines, to make sure the mines are sold only to signatories of the appropriate conventions and, importantly, to ensure there is good verification of the sale and distribution of landmines. This is the coalition's position. We have a proud record here. It was the Fraser government which signed the inhumane weapons agreement, and it is because we do not believe that a total ban is actually viable at present but believe that it is an aim which we should work towards that we are supporting the government amendment.

There is a need for Australia to make a thorough study of all conventional weapons of war and to seek to get an international treaty reducing the production, sale and usage of all such weapons. The banning of antipersonnel mines, particularly those which we are addressing tonight—those with no detectable metal involved, which are non-self-destructing—is a vital step in the right direction. It is a small step, but a very valuable one. The best testimonial for their banning will come from the many Australian medical officers who did the amputations, who did the radical surgery and who operated on mine victims throughout Asia.

The opposition believes the government's amendment represents the best chance of increasing the pressure on landmine producers and users and will therefore support the amendment. We look for continuing reviews of the convention over the next few years. But let us widen the issue. All weapons kill and maim people. We must ban the unlimited use of all weapons—not just nuclear ones, chemical ones, biological ones or ones which impact directly on civilians—because in the end war affects us all, civilians and soldiers alike.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are discussing the urgency motion concerning the need to implement a total ban on the production, transfer, sale, export, stockpiling or use of antipersonnel mines. Because of what has happened with the mining of the various battlefields and countries throughout the world, I suppose most senators in this place would agree with those sentiments. But it is also worth while noting that we are not living in a perfect world and that it is very difficult for that ban to be put into place. The government is about extracting the possible result that they can get. The possible result that they can get is the result that has been put before the convention.

PARA.TAB: By aiming for that result, we believe we will be lessening the problems that exist in the international community. A total ban, I believe, and I think some of the other speakers stated, would not be accepted by the international community and it would be doomed to failure. The Australian government's submission about changing the inhumane weapons convention is aimed at achieving the possible, given the fact that most governments are opposed to the total ban on landmining. The issue we are trying to address is the risk to civilians, the threat of unexploded mines after hostilities cease. Our priority has been to get support for a ban on the use of long-lived antipersonnel landmines and replace them with a limited life mine that will self-destruct.

The government's position is quite clear: the government is urging a ban on long-lived personnel landmines; that is, a ban on landmines which do not have a self-destructing and self-deactivating capability, a ban on non-detectable landmines, a ban on trade in any landmines which are not sanctioned by the convention, a ban on the supply of landmines to all countries not party to the convention, and an extension of the convention to cover internal conflicts and civil wars which would prevent the supply of landmines to non-government entities, such as the guerilla force in a particular country. Australia's proposals address the basic problems caused by the misuse of landmines and have a realistic chance of being widely accepted. It is a case of what is possible and acceptable to the international community that the government is pushing.

The government's position has been put forward by Gary Punch, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, and by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) on a number of occasions, including in an answer today to a question of Senator Bourne and in an answer to a question from Senator Margetts. Senator Margetts's question, which appears in the Hansard of 1 June this year on page 697, reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . both self-destruct and detectable landmines are far more expensive than cheaper plastic devices, why does the government believe that a partial ban on landmines would be all that effective?
Senator Evans replied:
The only reason we are opposing the banning absolutely of the production and deployment of landmines is that to seek to do that would be hopelessly utopian.
That is the difficulty that the government faces. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today is a national day of awareness of the atrocities caused by landmines. I rise to support the urgency motion of the Greens and the government amendment to it. I think the Senate should be grateful to the Greens for bringing this very important matter before the Senate. I also acknowledge the highly credible organisations that are voicing their concerns about the atrocities caused by these landmines. The Australian Medical Association, the Australian Conference of Catholic Bishops, the Pope and the International Red Cross have all lent their support to this cause.

PARA.TAB: I deplore the devastating results of antipersonnel landmines, the damage that they cause and the destructive effect on rendering the countryside unable to be used for primary industry or any other uses. I think someone once said, `War is hell.' No-one wants war, but it is unrealistic to expect Australia to unilaterally abandon the use of landmines when every army in the world utilises this method of warfare to some extent. In Australia's case, we have a huge and vast expanse of northern Australia which would be virtually impossible to defend without some judicious use of landmines. Everyone recognises the problems that landmines cause. They are a bit like nuclear weapons in that there is no use hiding our head and saying, `We are going to disadvantage our own side by not using landmines,' if every other nation with which we are in competition or are likely to be in competition is going to use these weapons of destruction.

The United Nations estimates that over 100 million mines lie unexploded in around 60 countries, many of these without record of their location, such as in Cambodia, Afghanistan, Mozambique, Angola, Somalia, El Salvador and the former Yugoslavia. The United States recognises that the total landmine numbers increase by one million each year. While precise international statistics are not kept on the landmine victims, the Human Rights Quarterly has figures stating that one out of 236—and I checked that statistic, because I thought it was extraordinarily high—have lost at least one limb due to the amputation following a mine explosion. In Angola the figure is one in 470, which is slightly less. Senator Margetts shakes her head in absolute disgust, and I concur with her feelings on this matter. During trips overseas, I have seen the devastation caused by these landmines. In a visit that I made to Mozambique five or six years ago, I saw young children with their limbs blown off, with one or two legs missing. I was absolutely shocked by the result of landmines.

The inhumane weapons convention in Australia will seek to bolster the 1980 agreement through calling for bans on non-detectable mines made of plastic. Australia will also be seeking a ban on the use of and trade in long life mines. Modern mines should be embodied with a mine deactivating mechanism. This would greatly reduce the incidence of innocent children tripping over mine wires 20 years after hostilities in the country have ceased, as is the case in Vietnam today.

Australia will also call for a ban on trade in mines with states and guerilla forces not party to the convention, and also request that the provisions of the convention be extended to international incursions and civil wars. I lend my support to the urgency motion and the government amendment. In closing, I recognise the concerns of all senators about the destruction of innocent people by these devastating weapons.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two minutes and 45 seconds to speak, so I seek the leave of the Senate to have incorporated in Hansard paragraphs 5.56, 5.57, 5.58, 5.59, 5.60, 5.61 and 5.62 of the report of the human rights subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade tabled at the end of December 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the leave absolutely.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

INTERJECT.PARA: 5.56Landmines have become the scourge of civilians in many countries in Africa, Asia, the Middle East and Europe. They are a major source of the continuing refugee problems in Pakistan and in parts of Africa. More than 300 million have been produced. The International Committee of the Red Cross estimates that over 100 million landmines have been scattered in 62 countries claiming 800 victims each month. The US State Department has made a much more conservative, but nevertheless fearful, estimate.

5.57Landmines are increasingly miniaturised and made of plastic components which are difficult to detect in the ground or on people. They are indiscriminate and last well beyond the conflict for which they are deployed. For instance, the Chinese T72 has a lithium battery which will last between 75 and 100 years.(40) For every person killed there are another two people on crutches or with artificial or missing limbs.(41) In Cambodia there are 4 million mines in a country of 8 million people. There are already 36,000 amputees. In Afghanistan, 20% (200,000) of the deaths in the civil war were caused by mines; 400,000 people were injured. In Angola one in 400 people is a surviving amputee; in Somalia, the figure is one in 650.(42)

5.58Removal of landmines is a dangerous, slow and expensive process. It is the work of individuals painstakingly testing the ground with prodders in order to uncover each mine. For every 5,000 mines cleared, one disposal expert is killed and two are injured. Landmines can be bought for as little as $3 but cost on average $1,000 per mine to clear. This cost does not take into account the costs of medical treatment, social security support, loss of working capacity and loss of land use. To understand the scope of the problem it is instructive to look at the example of Afghanistan. The devastating civil war and instability following the Soviet withdrawal has left 9-10 million mines scattered throughout the countryside. The International Committee of the Red Cross has estimated that at the current rate of removal it will take 4,300 years to clear 20 per cent of the country.(43) Starting in 1989, nine states, including Australia, despatched de-mining forces to remove and make mines safe through the UN Mine Clearance Training Team in Afghanistan (UNMCTT). While all nations except Norway withdrew their forces from Afghanistan in 1990 and 1991 for security reasons, Australia's team of initially six, later three ADF men remained until December 5, 1993, the last team to depart. Under UNTAC four million square metres of Cambodia were cleared of 37,000 landmines and 2,300 Cambodians were trained in mine clearance.(44)

5.59Landmines are manufactured by 48 countries. Major manufacturers, suppliers and traders have included: the United States, USSR, China, Italy, the United Kingdom, France, Czechoslovakia, Singapore, Egypt, Pakistan and South Africa.(45) Components are manufactured in countries which have nothing overtly to do with the manufacture of the landmines themselves. For example the Swedes, who do not produce landmines, nevertheless produce explosives for landmines.

5.60There has been mounting pressure in the international community, especially from NGOs, for new measures to control the manufacture and use of landmines. A landmark event was the Inhumane Weapons Convention, 1980, Protocol 11, 1981. However, only 39 countries have ratified this convention and the United States is a signatory but not a full member. In the United States the convention was still before the Senate in late 1994. Moreover, the convention lacks implementation provisions and does not apply to internal conflicts, which are the basis for UN peacekeeping in the post-Cold War era.

5.61Some advance in the control of landmines has been made with the unilateral moratorium which has been placed on their trade by the United States, France, Belgium and the Netherlands. Furthermore, at the International Conference for the Protection of War Victims in Geneva in August 1993, Australia called for a review of the 1980 convention. The proposal has come before the General Assembly for endorsement. The expert group has now met on three occasions and is due to meet once more, in January 1995, before the Review Conference, scheduled for 25 September to 13 October 1995.

5.62Australia has made representations to a number of regional countries including Brunei, Thailand, Philippines, Malaysia, Indonesia, Singapore, Vietnam, Burma, Republic of Korea, Papua New Guinea, Western Samoa, Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, Fiji and Kiribati, with a view to encouraging either ratification of the Inhumane Weapons Convention (IWC) or participation in the Review Conference. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade reported some regional reluctance to becoming part of the convention.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill makes amendments to the Health Insurance Act 1973 and the National Health Act 1953.

Amendments to the Health Insurance Act 1973 will allow the Health Insurance Commission to more effectively police and endorse arrangements relating to Temporary Resident Doctors (TRDs) and Occupational Trainees (OTs).

Amendments will also be made to the Health Insurance Act 1973 which relate to requirements for the payment of Medicare benefits for diagnostic imaging services. These amendments are designed to ensure that Medicare benefits are payable for diagnostic imaging services rendered by consultant physicians, to provide for the form of requests for diagnostic imaging services, and to provide for improved arrangements for remote area exemptions.

The amendments to be made to the National Health Act 1953 are to enact the decision taken in the 1995 Budget to raise the safety net which applies to general patients under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Preventing Temporary Resident Doctors and Occupational Trainees from Moonlighting

SPEECH.PARA: Each year in excess of 700 temporary resident doctors and 700 o occupational trainees enter the Australian medical workforce. These overseas temporary doctors are issued with conditional visas which restrict them to work only in specific `areas of need', that is, in specified public hospitals or underserviced rural and remote areas.

It has been conservatively estimated that at least 10 per cent of these doctors will be `moonlighting' to some extent. The term `moonlighting' refers to temporary resident doctors and occupational trainees performing services outside their `host' institution or specified area of need, usually billing against another doctor's provider number. This practice is in breach of the Health Insurance Act 1973, but is difficult to detect.

In the 1995 Federal Budget, it was announced that measures would be taken to reduce the number of temporary doctors `moonlighting' in the system. To achieve this, amendments to the Health Insurance Act 1973 are proposed. These amendments will enable the effective detection of moonlighting.
Specifically, they will:
1.restrict temporary resident doctors' and occupational trainees' eligibility to participate in Medicare benefits by amending the definition of `medical practitioner';

2.amend the definition of `professional service', in order to prevent one doctor from providing a service on behalf of another doctor, but not to prevent a nurse or allied health worker working under the supervision of doctors to do so; and

3.allow the Department of Immigration and Ethnic affairs to provide the information necessary to enable the Health Insurance Commission to trace those temporary resident doctors and occupational trainees practising outside any conditions imposed on them and to enable those temporary resident doctors and occupational trainees who are in breach of their visa conditions to be identified to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
It is estimated that these measures will result in savings of $18.5 million over the next four years.

The proposed amendments should have no impact on those medical practitioners who are complying with the provisions of the Health Insurance Act. The amendments will, however, ensure that no medical practitioner will be able to "hide" behind another medical practitioner, except for the purposes of legitimate training. In addition to achieving savings in Medicare outlays, these amendments will reinforce the objectives of the National Medical Workforce Strategy agreed by Health Ministers in 1992 to reduce the impact of overseas trained doctors on the Australian medical workforce.

The bill will also provide that Medicare benefits are payable for diagnostic imaging services rendered by consultant physicians; amend provisions concerning the form of requests for diagnostic imaging services; and provide for improved arrangements for remote area exemptions.

Amendments to the Health Insurance Act 1973 which came into effect from 1 May 1991 implemented a formal mechanism for requesting diagnostic imaging services, specified activities which were deemed to be prohibited practices, and other matters. This included a provision that Medicare benefits were not payable for a diagnostic imaging service unless the rendering medical practitioner had received a written request for the service from another medical practitioner or, for certain prescribed items, a written request from a dental practitioner, a chiropractor, a physiotherapist or a podiatrist.

Certain exceptions and exemptions from the written request provisions were put in place and these included an exception that certain services rendered by a specialist practising in his or her specialty, following a written request, attracted Medicare benefits at a higher rate than would apply if the service was rendered by a practitioner who was not a specialist or who rendered the service outside his or her specialty.

The lower rate traditionally related to services which were seen as falling within the competence of general practitioners and included x-rays of the extremities, chest and abdomen. The higher rate related to the same services when rendered by specialist radiologists after the receipt of a written request. The existing provisions allow Medicare benefits to be payable at the higher rate when these services are rendered by any specialist while practising in his or her specialty.

An exemption from the written request requirement is also granted where services are rendered by a specialist in the course of practising in his or her specialty (other than in diagnostic radiology) and where that specialist had determined that the service was necessary.

The exceptions and provisions did not refer specifically to consultant physicians who rendered a diagnostic imaging service in similar circumstances. Consultant physicians and specialists both possess the same qualifications and have undergone the same training. However, a consultant physician must conduct a wholly referred practice exclusively in their specialty.

While it was intended that consultant physicians be treated under the provisions in the same way as specialists, there is doubt that the wording of the provisions authorise the payment of Medicare benefits in those same circumstances to consultant physicians.

To clarify the matter, the bill provides specifically for Medicare benefits to be payable to patients for diagnostic imaging services rendered by consultant physicians when rendered in the same circumstances by specialists, and provides that the Commonwealth will not recover payment of Medicare benefits paid to patients in respect of those services from 1 May 1991, the date from which the changes became operative.

The bill also provides that the form and content of written requests for diagnostic imaging services by dental practitioners, chiropractors, physiotherapists and podiatrists may be prescribed in the same way as those by medical practitioners.

The bill allows for remote area exemptions to be for a shorter term than the present fixed period of three years. It provides for exemptions to be granted from the date the application was received rather than from the date on which the exemption was granted, which could be some weeks after the practitioner applied for exemption due, for example, to a delay in making a decision because an application was being investigated. The provisions are designed to reduce inconvenience to patients who receive diagnostic imaging services provided by rural medical practitioners, such as practitioners just taking up practice, or locums at a practice for a few weeks.

This bill also gives effect, by changes to the National Health Act 1953, to the decision announced in the 1995-96 Budget to change the safety net arrangements applying to general patients under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS).

The PBS has for more than forty years been providing the Australian community with access to necessary medications and enjoys international recognition for its success. However, with an ageing population and the development of new drugs, the costs of operating the PBS are increasing every year. In 1993-94, for example, the cost of the Scheme increased to approximately $1.7 billion. This cost must be borne by the taxpayer.

The PBS safety net, which was introduced in 1986 to help patients who require a lot of medication, will remain available. There will be no changes to the safety net arrangements for pensioners and other concessional beneficiaries.

For general patients, the safety net threshold will be increased from $407.60 in 1995 to $600 for the calendar year 1996, with this amount to be indexed for subsequent years in accordance with movements in the Consumer Price Index. Once a general patient and members of the patient's family have this amount recorded on their Prescription Record Form, pharmaceutical benefits will be available at the concessional rate of $2.60 (indexed) per prescription for the remainder of the calendar year.
This change is estimated to reduce outlays on the PBS by $10 million in 1995-96 and by $30 million in subsequent years.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: AIRCRAFT NOISE LEVY BILL 1995AIRCRAFT NOISE LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 9 June, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening the Senate is debating the Aircraft Noise Levy Bill and the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Bill. It is interesting to note that before the end of the last session in June the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) claimed that we on this side of the Senate had held up this legislation.

PARA.TAB: What happened, as everyone knows, is that we had the grossest example of mismanagement that I have seen since coming into this place. We had a minister who, as Manager of Government Business in the Senate, was all over the place, did not know what his program was all about and it never got up. Then the minister put out a release saying that the opposition was responsible for their mismanagement.

Then this bill appeared in the first week—in other words, last week—after we came back from the winter recess. It appeared on the first day of the first week and then it disappeared again. I drew the minister's attention to that and he then put out a press release and said, `That was because of Fred Daly's death.' Everyone was very sorry about Fred Daly, and Senator Jones gave a very wonderful speech on the subject.

But let me say that this minister comes from that group in New South Wales who do not care what they say. The postponement of this bill had nothing whatsoever to do with the death of Fred Daly. The bill had already passed through the House of Representatives. The condolence motion speeches in this place were not expected to be as long as they were in the House of Representatives—and they were not. But he actually said, `The reason why I postponed this bill was because of the unfortunate death of Fred Daly.' It is something I think Fred himself would have enjoyed immensely, and I am sure he would have told the story over and over again.

The purpose of these bills is to impose a tax on most jet aircraft landing at airports where the Commonwealth is funding noise amelioration programs. The bills were developed as part of the government's noise management plan for Sydney airport, which is currently the only airport where aircraft operators would be subject to the tax.

The government recently announced that it would be implementing noise amelioration programs around Coolangatta and Adelaide and that the levy would be extended to those airports when the program started. The main sections of the Aircraft Noise Levy Bill are clauses 5 and 6, which set out the method of calculating the levy. The levy would only be imposed on jet aircraft. It would not apply to aircraft operated by the Defence Force, the military, police or customs services of another country, nor would it apply to emergency or charitable flights.

Clause 6 of the bill sets out the formula for calculating the levy, which would be imposed on any given aircraft based on a constant levy unit and then multiplied by a factor derived from the noise generated by the aircraft. The levy unit would have to be the same for all the leviable airports in Australia.

The levy collection bill would enact the mechanisms for enforcing and collecting the levy. Sections 6 and 7 of the bill map out the process of identifying airports where levies are required and for declaring those levies. Section 6 requires the Minister for Transport to identify as qualifying airports all the airports throughout Australia that meet a number of requirements.

An airport is defined as a qualifying one if: firstly, there is a public building within the 25 Australian noise exposure forecast contour for the airport; or, secondly, there is a residence within the 30 ANEF contour; and, thirdly, the Commonwealth is already funding a noise amelioration program for the airport.

The ANEF system is mathematically based and attempts to assess the impact of aircraft noise around an airport. It takes into account the number, the noise level and the time of day of all aircraft overflights affecting a given location and this is then averaged out over a long period of time. The results of the calculations are customarily presented as a series of contour lines on a map of the area surrounding the airport. The Senate committee looking at Sydney airport has heard a lot of reservations about this system as a method of forewarning people about what they can expect; but I will come to that later.

Section 7 of the bill would require the minister to impose the levy on every airport qualified under section 6 and the minister would have to issue a declaration specifying the time the levy would be imposed.

The aircraft noise levy bills are an integral part of the government's plan to insulate or acquire the homes and public buildings to the north of Sydney airport that are worst affected by aircraft noise. The government is in the process of buying 113 homes that are the worst affected. It plans to insulate 4,200 houses and units inside the 30 ANEF contour and schools, child-care facilities, health-care facilities and churches inside the 25 ANEF contour. The Department of Administrative Services is currently conducting a pilot study of 18 homes to determine the best forms of insulation.

I and my other Senate colleagues have examined the Sydney airport insulation program over the last few months in our role on the Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise. The draft noise management plan recommended that the government insulate the homes in the 30 ANEF contour in accordance with Australian Standard 2021, which recommended that noise levels inside bedrooms should not exceed 50 decibels and that noise levels inside the other rooms of a domestic residence should not exceed 60 decibels.
The amount of work required on individual homes to achieve these tasks would vary considerably, depending on their location and the type of construction.

Most of the homes in the insulation area are made out of brick, which in itself is a relatively good insulator. However, the windows of most homes would need to be double glazed and this has caused all sorts of problems with protuberances now jutting into rooms and the inability of people, for example, to put up curtains. The doors would need to be replaced by four centimetre thick solid core doors with plastic seals around the frames. Some of the recipients of the pilot program have complained that their children now have difficulty shutting and opening those particular doors. So even with the best will in the world this thing will not go through smoothly.

Most of the homes in the area would also require modifications to their roofs and ceilings, which are designed to keep out the weather, not the sound of howling jet aeroplanes. On one of the buildings we saw, in fact, it was obvious that you just could not put batts in the way you would for heating purposes; you would have to cover the whole ceiling. There could not be one crack or chink, otherwise the noise would get through. Complaints are being made, for instance, that with those insulations that are being carried out all the electrical wires have been covered up, so they cannot now get to the electrical wires within the ceilings.

TALK.START.PARA: —But that happens in most houses, even new ones built today.
—You have to be able to get to the electrical wires. You must deal with bodgie builders—probably from the BLF!

PARA.TAB: The other thing that was drawn to our attention was the sound insulation of weatherboard homes. The difficulties there were they had to skirt the whole underneath of the house. The claim was made that this would lead to dry rot and the introduction of white ants where the breeze has to be chopped off to get it through. I am just giving you some of the examples we saw. We might have seen the worst—and we saw others at the same time—but this was the sort of thing we saw.

We inspected a number of houses in the pilot program. One of the houses we inspected highlights the difficulties in retrofitting insulation into old buildings that are so common in the insulation area. One we looked at was a workers' cottage in Albany Road, Petersham, with a slate roof. It had partly been restored by its owners. As you enter the house, you pass three bedrooms on your right, before entering the living room through a fully restored half glazed door. The eat-in kitchen, laundry and bathroom are located in the unrestored section of the house, which has a flat corrugated iron roof. The maximum level of decibel noise in the house is about 86. Now that's loud.

My main concern about the work done on this house was the decision not to insulate the kitchen. Those sorts of things are happening. I will not go into all the details of it. Many of the homes, of course, date back to the first decades of this century. It is a specialist's job. I am not being critical of the people doing it and the pilot program, I think you have to go through that. However, I wonder whether there are enough specialist builders around to be able to carry out this work within the time frame and within the cost claimed by the government—and I will be asking a couple of questions about that.

The government must ensure that all people who live in houses like the one in Albany Road receive the same level of noise protection as everyone else. It must give them the opportunity to renovate their homes to the required standard before the insulation is installed.

In my view, the cost of the program has been underestimated considerably. The draft noise management plan said in June last year that the program would cost $130 million. In November, the government claimed that it would cost $183 million. Six months later the budget, we are told, will be $260 million.

So over a period of time from the draft noise management plan in June last year, we have seen the estimate go from $130 million to $183 million, to $260 million. The estimated cost has increased 100 per cent over the original figures already and there are still 3,180 homes to go.
The program's three-year time frame may also be overly optimistic. That program, let me tell honourable senators, means that one home must be insulated every six hours—every six hours!

Slippages are appearing already. The pilot program was scheduled to be completed by the end of June and, as I understand it, the report still has not been finalised. The 20 schools in the program were supposed to be insulated by the end of the first term this year. Work on the scheme did not even start until March, and I will be extremely surprised if the program is completed on schedule and on budget.

I will, Madam Deputy President, be moving a second reading amendment to the Aircraft Noise Levy Bill condemning the government for misleading the people of Sydney about the level of noise that would be associated with the opening of the parallel runway and the closure of the east-west runway. The amendment will also condemn the government for its failure to develop adequate noise management measures before the closure of the east-west runway.

The government misled the people of Sydney about the level of noise that would be associated with the closure of the east-west runway and the opening of the new runway. It was not the new runway that caused the problem. The new runway is south of the east-west runway and east of the main north-south runway. Theoretically, there should have been an improvement in the movement of aircraft and aircraft cannot take off on the new runway. So they cannot take off when they make the most noise over the northern suburbs of Sydney; they can only take off to the south. And from what we have seen there are no problems on take-offs to the south on either of those two runways. But the real problem came when they virtually closed the east-west, and I will talk about that a little later.

The information that the government supplied to Sydney residents was based almost exclusively on the ANEF contour system. People who phoned the authorities, whether it be the CAA or the FAC, for additional information were always referred back to the ANEF contour map published in the draft noise management plan. If they were not on the map they did not think they were going to encounter a problem, but the material published by the government was almost impossible to understand for the ordinary citizen.

The system attempts to measure the community's response to aircraft noise. The residents of Sydney did not want to know that 20 per cent of the people in the 20 ANEF contour would be seriously affected by noise. They wanted to know how often planes would be flying over their homes and how noisy they would be. They were the simple things that people wanted; they did not get it from the system.

The CAA conceded this in its submission to our inquiry: The intense public reaction to exposure to new noise that accompanied the introduction of parallel runway operations at Sydney is clear evidence of the need to supplement the ANEF contours with a range of other metrics, such as the number of times that aircraft noise will exceed a given maximum noise level in a typical day.

SPEECH.PARA: The material published by the government stated that people living outside the 20 ANEF contour would not be affected significantly. That is quite clearly incorrect. Those of us who attended those meetings heard people from places like Hunters Hill and Lane Cove say that they strongly disagreed, if they could heard be over the sound of the jets.

PARA.TAB: The government decided to direct all the traffic through Sydney airport over one part of the city. It then deceived the people who live there about the effect the decision would have on their lives. My amendment will condemn the government for its failure to develop adequate noise management measures before the east-west runway was closed and the third runway was opened. It is a misnomer to talk about a third runway. There are only two. There were two before. They have built another one and closed one, so we are back to two. That is very clever mathematics.

The Minister for Transport's first attempt at developing a program was his announcement of the $183 million package on 1 November 1994. In early December, with community outrage growing, he announced a revision to that package that accelerated the insulation program and implemented a range of other measures, such as the designated flight paths, which have caused all the misery. In the budget, the government shovelled even more money into the insulation program. There is no reason why these measures could not have been implemented before the closure of the east-west runway and the opening of the new parallel runway. The government could have started buying houses in the worst affected areas before it made those changes in November.
Last week, Mr Brereton announced that the government will be implementing an insulation program for Adelaide. The Adelaide Advertiser quoted Mr Brereton as saying this:

SPEECH.PARA: I like to learn by the mistakes that have been made and there were plenty made in Sydney.
He and his government have been responsible for those mistakes. He is the minister responsible for developing the noise management initiatives at the airport.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to ask why this bill is before us now. This time 12 months ago, noise was an issue—it is always an issue at airports—but not a major issue. People were not marching in the streets. They were not driving their trucks and cars to blockade Sydney airport. It is an issue now, but why is it an issue now? What happened in November 1994?

The east-west runway was virtually closed and the new runway was opened. Instead of aircraft being spread around Sydney, which had always been the case previously, a narrow flight corridor was introduced. This grossly affected two groups of people. One was the Labor heartland, which includes places such as Marrickville and Leichhardt. People there had bought homes under flight paths at a discounted price. They had lived under aeroplanes. Apparently, one aeroplane every five, six or seven minutes did not bother them. They were used to it. But they then found themselves, in peak periods, getting an aircraft over their roof taking off or landing once every two minutes. It was the final straw.

Mr Brereton referred to the other group after the state election when he said that the election showed that it was not an issue. I am not going to pre-empt the committee in any way, but the committee has received over 3,500 individual submissions, and that does not include form letters. If you wanted to work out some rule of thumb which statisticians would use about how many people have not written compared with those that have, you would be looking at 400,000 or 500,000 people who continue to be irate. It is a problem that will not go away.

The other group affected is comprised of those who never thought that they would have a plane flying over their roof. They bought their homes in areas that were well outside recognised flight paths. They are now being subjected to noise to such an extent that people from the CAA who are visiting some of those places around Hunters Hill to go and hear the noise for themselves have remarked to those communities, `We did not know it was as bad as this.' They have had the job of carrying it. I have some sympathy for those people, because they have all been innocently affected.

The government must answer a great number of questions. For example, what will be the cost of the insulation program? It has already blown out by over 100 per cent. Will the government be able to insulate a house every six hours if it keeps its promise of the time factor involved? Are there homes which, because of their structure, cannot be insulated? If so, what will it do about that? Are there schools that cannot be insulated? We saw one that is claimed to not be able to be insulated. The whole mess of Sydney airport, of which this process of the levy is just a part, is probably one of the biggest bungles in history ever inflicted on the people of Sydney by any government. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add:
"but the Senate condemns the Government for its callous and incompetent policy on Sydney Airport, and condemns it in particular:

PARA.TAB: (a)for misleading the people of Sydney about the noise that would be associated with the opening of the parallel runway and the closure of the east west runway; and

(b)for its failure to develop adequate noise management measures prior to the opening of the parallel runway and the closure of the east west runway, rather than after it had opened in a belated response to community pressure".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will briefly take the time of the Senate to support Senator Parer. He has basically said all that needs to be said about the Aircraft Noise Levy Bill 1995 and the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Bill 1995. What we are dealing with is purely a political response to an indescribably huge mess that the government has got itself into through its own incompetence. I am not a lawyer, but I remember people saying years ago something to the effect that hard cases make bad law. To design bills about the situation that exists at present at Sydney airport, with all the shortcomings that this legislation has, is really quite pointless.

PARA.TAB: Senator Parer said that this is almost an open-ended commitment. You cannot really be concerned about noise in Sydney yet expose every other resident to similar noise from jets at all the other airports in Australia. Who knows where this will end. There are physical demands on insulating houses as a consequence of these bills. As Senator Parer said, one will have to be done every six hours to stay with the program. It is clearly quite impossible.

The government should have been handling its affairs much better. Even at this late stage, it should be enforcing the use of quieter aircraft on the Australian airlines. When jet aircraft were first introduced, they were turbo jets. Later, they went to turbo fans. There has been a very significant reduction in noise output from jet aircraft. You only have to listen to some of the old service aircraft, such as the American KC135 tankers—similar aircraft to the Boeing 707s—with the early generation engines, not the new engines, taking off under full load at an Australian airport to know how far we have come at reducing the noise output from jet engines.

The British Aerospace 146 is cleared for operation at most airports around the world not subject to a curfew because it is just so quiet. Paradoxically, under this legislation, it is more heavily penalised than aircraft like the Boeing 727. That leads me to another point. Why is the government allowing Ansett to keep operating Boeing 727s in Australia? They clearly infringe the category 3 noise standards that were agreed internationally quite a few years ago. I am not sure of the implementation date, but in the immediate future the aircraft themselves must be written down to a negligible depreciation value at Ansett. They would have had the youngest of them for at least 15 years by my reckoning. Probably 20 years would be the average fleet age.

On the same topic, it is interesting that, because they are noisy aircraft, they never go into Sydney. The Boeing 727s that Ansett has are inflicted on the good burghers of Melbourne and Brisbane. They more or less run a direct Brisbane-Melbourne route exclusively with the 727s. Presumably that is because the Brisbane and Melbourne residents do not kick up the fuss that the Sydney people do. That aircraft should be removed from regular Australian public transport service along with the F28, because they are both old aircraft and they are incredibly noisy.

One of the other things the government could do is control the approach paths to the airports and stop fresh building taking place under the approach paths. It is a bit difficult in places like Sydney which are very built up. There is a classic case in Brisbane. The Cannon Hill saleyards—the meatworks—Borthwicks, which is on the south bank of the river, is almost directly under the approach path to the main runway at the new Brisbane airport.

The Labor Party at both state and council levels wants to sock a whole lot of residential buildings into that area and develop that site. That site really ought to be zoned for industrial use or parkland. Goodness knows, Brisbane has very little parkland within its perimeter. The proposal that Cannon Hill should be built up as a high density residential area is quite nonsensical. Brisbane airport is not going to move as Sydney airport is. This is creating problems for the future. Those residential areas could be redesigned and the problem could be averted.

Part of the problem also results from the way the government has messed up the Civil Aviation Authority and its successors, whatever they might be called at the present time. I read in the Financial Review of 7 June this year that the commissioning of the new control tower at Sydney airport, which would play a key role in the management of traffic into Sydney airport, has been deferred indefinitely. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Plans to expand capacity at Sydney Airport to ease congestion have slipped further with nagging computer software problems forcing an indefinite delay in the opening of the new high-technology control tower.

PARA.TAB: The Civil Aviation Authority yesterday admitted that the tower would not be ready to begin operation on June 10, as the acting chief executive Mr Buck Brooksbank had indicated just two weeks ago.
It was the third embarrassing delay for what the CAA had hailed in its recent newspaper advertising campaign as "the best-equipped control tower of any airport in the world".

SPEECH.PARA: As far as I know, no date has been given for the commissioning of the new tower at Sydney. Of course that gets back to the government's mismanagement, through the CAA, of the contract. I presume it is the TAAATS contract with Thomson. It is not surprising that Thomson, with its small resources in air traffic control and simple systems, is running into difficulty. PARA.TAB: The reason for the two bills is pure incompetence on the part of the government. This is just a window dressing, political exercise to try to get them past the angry electors of the city of Sydney in the election. I have news for the government: the angry electors are not going to be assuaged by such a transparent and dishonest attempt to cope with the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of Senator Parer's amendment to the Aircraft Noise Levy Bill and the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Bill. I wish to make two points. I support the first part of his amendment which indicates that the government misled the people of Sydney about the third runway when it was opened. The people of Sydney and New South Wales were promised a third runway. They actually finished up with 1 1/2 runways. The second aspect of his amendment relates to the fact that an adequate noise study strategy was not prepared. I think that the public angst and outcry about the noise has been clearly evidenced by a lack of planning.

PARA.TAB: The second point I would like to make is that I do not think the fact that the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) pre-empted the findings of our inquiry via a public statement on 3 August can be ignored. The people of Sydney were misled by this federal Labor government as to the effect of the third runway. I think it is acknowledged that the noise abatement work should have been undertaken before the third runway came into operation.

A pilot study has been conducted with 20 houses being insulated using a variety of materials and techniques. We have certainly heard evidence that there is a degree of concern about the way the pilot study has been implemented and the cost of the study. It has cost $1 million to insulate 20 houses. A cost of $50,000 a house is certainly a very expensive way of insulating those houses against noise. At least their problem is being partially addressed.

This pilot study is the precursor to a wider program which will insulate more than 4,000 houses and should see many schools insulated by the end of the September school holidays. The cost, which has blown out to twice the original estimation, has already been mentioned by Senator Parer. I am sure it will go higher. This legislation is primarily being introduced to pay for this.

I do not want to dwell on the actual way the noise contour maps were drawn up and the sort of dissatisfaction that many residents of Sydney feel about the method used to calculate the effect of noise. I would like to turn to the action of Minister Brereton which served to politicise the airport noise issue. Several weeks ago Mr Brereton reaffirmed that the government would not reopen the east-west runway. I considered that it was a blatant attempt to pre-empt the outcome of the inquiry.

I guess that sort of behaviour is to be expected of Minister Brereton. He is the sort of person who can bully and connive and do almost anything to get his way. In passing, I point out that the New South Wales Right of the ALP will do or say anything to get their own way. He does not like the way this inquiry is going. I guess his comments were a result of that.

As Senator Parer said, the Senate Select Committee into Aircraft Noise has received an unprecedented number of submissions—around 4,000. That shows the degree of angst and worry that the people of Sydney have. I think Minister Brereton's decision to concentrate the airport noise into two narrow flight paths has been a social, environmental, health and political disaster.

Today, we are debating a bill designed to ease the burden on those suffering under Sydney flight paths. The Aircraft Noise Levy Bill will impose a levy on aircraft noise at designated state and internal territory airports. The bill is designed to recover the costs associated with noise amelioration works currently proposed and being trialled in Sydney. Noisy aircraft such as the B747 will pay four times more than quieter aircraft like the Boeing 737. The target collection of $32 million in 1995-96 represents approximately $3.40 per passenger for a jet landing at Sydney airport.

Minister Brereton's comments on 3 August this year basically pre-empt the outcome of the Senate select committee's hearings and findings. Minister Brereton released a computer simulation of a near collision of two passenger jets in 1991. An Ansett Airbus came within 11 metres of colliding with a Thai DC-10.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Ethnic Ukrainians in the Former Yugoslavia

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want tonight to bring to the attention of the Senate the plight of ethnic Ukrainians caught in the conflict in Bosnia and other parts of the former Yugoslavia. I do so after discussions in recent days with the President of the Australian Federation of Ukrainian Organisations in Australia, Mr Stefan Romaniw; the Chairman of the Committee for the Defence of Ukrainians in the former Yugoslavia, Mr Marian Tkaczuk; and the Bishop of the Ukrainian Catholic Church in Australia, New Zealand and Oceania, Bishop Peter Stasiuk.

PARA.TAB: There are several thousand ethnic Ukrainians in Bosnia. They are a small ethnic minority. Ethnic Ukrainians have lived in Bosnia for more than 100 years, mainly in the north-west region of the country. Their main centres of spiritual and cultural life are Bania Luka and Prnjavor. They live in the parishes of Kozarec, Devjatyna, Lyshria and Derventa, along with other communities in those areas. Up to 6,000 ethnic Ukrainians lived in those places before the war in the former Yugoslavia. As a result of the war, several entire parishes, including Kamenycia and Dubrova, have disappeared completely. People have been dispossessed and expelled from areas they have lived in for all of their lives.

Today, I am told, more than half the ethnic Ukrainians affected now live outside Bosnia as a result of the war and its impact on them. Although we tend to think of the war in Bosnia as only involving Serbs, Croats and Muslims, there are also other minority groups there that are as affected by the war in many respects as are the ones we hear about—the Serbs, the Croats and the Muslims—and one of those groups is the Ukrainians.

The Ukrainians, as I say, have lived in the area for more than 100 years. According to the Australian Federation of Ukrainian Organisations, with whom I have had correspondence, and Bishop Tkaczuk, the Ukrainian bishop in Australia—as well as some religious leaders who visited Bosnia a few months ago—there is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . mass dispossessions and evictions from their family homes of many generations. There are reports coming through relating instances of torture, rape and murder inflicted on ethnic Ukrainians.

. . . being regarded as so called "foreigners" in the conflict, Ukrainians are being victimised and "used" extensively by all sides involved, often becoming front line fodder and being sent back to the front despite injuries suffered. It has been stated that there is no place for Ukrainians in the post-war Bosnia.

As we know, there is a very significant human tragedy going on particularly in Bosnia and other parts of the former Yugoslavia. At the moment we are aware of aspects of it. I think this aspect, so far as ethnic minorities are concerned, is something that has not been brought to the attention of the Australian community or the government until recently. It is a matter about which all Australians would be very concerned, given the large, significant and wonderful Ukrainian population and community that we have here in Australia.

PARA.TAB: There are about 1,200 members of the Ukrainian community who were born in Bosnia who are now living in Australia. They are very concerned for their relatives in Bosnia. I understand the Ukrainian Catholic Church and other members of the Ukrainian community are contacting and have been in touch with the Australian government to bring to the government's attention the plight of these people.

Bishop Stasiuk of the Ukrainian Catholic Church in Australia estimates there would be some 3,000 to 4,000 people who fit into this category who may wish to come to Australia simply to leave the outrage of war behind and to lead a decent life of peace in a new land. From talking with the Ukrainian community in Australia, I know that Ukrainians around Australia are making plans to receive family members and fellow countrymen if they are allowed to come to Australia.

It is a very difficult subject. Australia's refugee and humanitarian program for this year totals only 13,000. Of that, I think there are only about 4,000 places for refugees as defined by the United Nations convention on refugees. So the prospect of all those people being able to live here or migrate here as refugees or those in need of humanitarian care is a very difficult issue, given all the other demands on Australia from other war torn areas around the world.

It is important to make sure that we in Australia do not neglect because of ignorance the plight of these people. I ask the government to make sure that we have a place for those most in need, at least in terms of consideration of their needs, and that they are not neglected and, for bureaucratic or other reasons, omitted from the equation of people who may be eligible for refugee and humanitarian assistance here.

I bring this matter to the attention of the Senate. I will be supporting the Ukrainian communities here in Australia by bringing it to the attention of the government. I know there have been some discussions with the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I hope those discussions will prove positive so we in Australia can fully take into account the legitimate and very understandable concerns of the Ukrainian community here in Australia about their compatriots, at least in the sense of their ethnic compatriots—Ukrainians who have lived and had their home in Bosnia and other parts of the former Yugoslavia for many generations now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I speak, I want to declare an interest in the particular subject that I am raising tonight. It is an interest which has only become apparent in the past few days. It is concerned with two sandmining projects which are reasonably close to where I live in the Caboolture area.

PARA.TAB: The first project is not of great proximity to me and, as a result, I do not have a direct interest in it. This is a project to quarry sand and gravel in the Beachmere area. Beachmere is a seaside town on the other side of the Bribie Passage from Bribie Island in Queensland. I have been involved with this particular issue for about 12 months. I have facilitated and supported the protest and the objection to the proposal by almost the whole population of the town of Beachmere.

Having been involved with that particular protest for about 12 months, it was to my surprise and chagrin that just a couple of weeks ago I discovered that there was an even larger proposal to quarry sand and gravel which was going to directly affect a property which I own. This project is at the seaside village of Maldale and is not too far from the Beachmere project.

Caboolture, being only 50 kilometres from the city, has been developing as almost a residential satellite suburb of Brisbane. We now have proposals which appear to almost make the Caboolture area a gravel pit for the supply of gravel and sand for building in Brisbane. I want to put on record the reasons why these projects create great problems. Most of the issues are common to both areas, but there are a couple of additional problems which are peculiar to the Beachmere project.

There is a very significant traditional Aboriginal camping and burial place near Beachmere. The position is evidenced by the presence of archaeological shell middens and other indications. The camping and burial places are of cultural importance to the Aboriginal community and are of such archaeological importance that they need to be preserved. Maldale and Beachmere are seaside residential areas and the amenities of both areas will be adversely affected by very large sandmining projects. They will be affected by noise, dust and pollution of the water. One of the concerns of the people in the Beachmere area is that Bestmann Road, which is the access road into the sandmining area, will be very adversely affected by the noise of empty trucks travelling to the subject land and by loaded trucks travelling from the project. These trucks will travel right through the middle of a residential area. These are significant issues which ought to be noted by the Senate.

Another issue concerning both areas is the prevalence of acid sulfate soils. Test holes which have been bored indicate that the acid sulfate soils are a very serious problem. They exist right up and down the east coast of Australia. While they are left in situ these soils are no problem at all. The problem occurs when these soils are brought to the surface. The particular minerals in the acid sulfate soils become oxidised and, when mixed with water, form sulfuric acid. As a result, the marine environment is polluted and we have a dangerous situation for marine life and birds. The water becomes polluted and this affects the people in both areas who have bores.

As a result we have a very serious threat to a number of prawn farms on Bullock Creek and Elimbah Creek, the two creeks that border the projected sandmining proposal in the Maldale area. There is a real conflict in land use. It seems to me that in Australia we are facing these kinds of conflicts all the time and they are very hard to resolve. We have conflict between mining and agricultural use from time to time. Here we have conflict between the quarrying of sand and residential use, rural use and aquaculture.

These issues have to be resolved. Sunfish, the large corporation in Queensland which deals particularly with professional fishing, and the Department of Environment and Heritage are both very solidly opposed to these two proposals. We are concerned that such a large extractive industry would make these areas quite unlivable. They would threaten the industry currently being conducted there. The residents and the Department of Environment and Heritage believe that certain controls should be put in place. However, if they were put in place they would make the extractive industry quite unviable. It seems strange that the companies involved are pressing ahead with the proposals to quarry.

There are a number of other problems associated with the projects. My nine acres is in an area where there are a number of families. We have many bus routes which service the large numbers of children who travel to school each day in Caboolture. We have seen a much heavier use of these roads in the last couple of months as a result of the fires which swept through the area last year and burnt out a large portion of the pine plantations. The timber in those plantations has been harvested and the trucks involved in this project have caused a lot of congestion on these roads. However, the use of the roads by those trucks will finish very shortly when all the timber has been harvested. The transportation of material from the proposed extractive industry will continue for many years. There is a terrible conflict here between the various current uses of the land and any possible future uses. I support the concerns of the people in the area. The only solution I can see is for the companies concerned to seek out sand and gravel in areas which are not as fragile or as sensitive as the areas in which they now have applications to open up these mining projects. It does not seem to me that it is possible to hold together the various land uses which I have described.
