ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Bureau of Resource Science: Herbicide-Tolerant Plant Agriculture

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 1 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to a June 1995 visit of two Bureau Resource Sciences (BRS) officials travelling to a conference on the agricultural industry in Malaysia to promote the use of herbicide-tolerant plants:

(1) How is the above travel and conference consistent with the mission statement of the department, which states `the department's mission is to contribute to the sustainable, competitive growth of Australia's resource based industries'.

(2) How is the above travel and conference consistent with the mission statement of the BRS, which is `to enhance the sustainable development of Australia's agricultural, mineral, petroleum, forestry and fisheries resources and their industries by providing high quality scientific and technical advice to government, industry and the community'.
(3) (a) Was the trip funded by the department and/or BRS; and (b) what proportion and from what specific programs did the money come.

(4) (a) Is it true that herbicide corporations will benefit from the promotion of herbicide-tolerant plant (HTP) agriculture; (b) were these officials acting on behalf of the herbicide corporations at the conference, in their private capacity or in their working capacity; (c) is there a significant conflict of interest in funding officials to act on behalf of the herbicide corporations that will benefit from the promotion of HTP agriculture.

(5) Did the department or BRS send officials to promote non-chemical dependent agricultural techniques; if not, does this represent a bias or a failure to fulfill the mission statements of either the department or BRS in a fair and proper manner.

(6) (a) What proportion of the work that the department and BRS does can be classified as the development, encouragement, research and marketing of HTP agriculture; and (b) what is the proportion compared with organic agriculture development, encouragement, research and marketing.
(7) What sort of agriculture does the Government classify as: (a) sustainable; and (b) compatible with the clean foods export program; and why.

(8) (a) Is HTP agriculture compatible with the clean foods export program; if so and why; and (b) is it the perception of the general public that HT agriculture produces `clean food' in Australia and in our overseas markets.

(9) Is it a fact that HTP research support by the department and BRS is not capable of sustainable growth and therefore falls outside of both institutions' mission statements; if so will the Government withdraw all levels of support for HTP research, development, encouragement and marketing.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1, 2 ,3,4 and 5) There was no visit to Malaysia by Bureau of Resource Sciences (BRS) officials in June 1995. No BRS officials have travelled overseas in connection with any issue relating to HTP.
(6) (a) None; BRS staff have been looking at the issue with a view to promoting informed debate on this emerging technology and advising Government.

(b) It is not the role of BRS or DPIE to undertake or promote research into organic agriculture. Research into organic agriculture is funded by the R & D Corporations. The BRS has been analysing the growing international trend to reduce pesticide use and to promote the benefits that would flow from more efficient pesticide use in Australia. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service has developed a program to audit and accredit organic industry organisations against the Organic Produce Advisory Committee Standards, in order to meet overseas import requirements.
(7) (a) The former Standing Committee of Agriculture's Report on "Sustainable Agriculture" defined `sustainable agriculture' as the use of farming practices and systems which maintain or enhance:
the economic viability of agricultural production;
the natural resource base; and
other ecosystems which are influenced by agricultural activities.
(b) Sustainable agriculture, as described in 7(a) above, is entirely compatible with the clean foods export program, because such practices will lead to the production of clean food.

(8) (a) Yes to the extent that the growing of herbicide tolerant crops can result in the use of environmentally benign chemicals for weed control. There is every expectation that the technology will lead to the application of significantly less pesticide than is currently used.
(b) The Government is not in a position to comment on the public perception of HTP agriculture, nor is the Government in a position to comment on how overseas markets view the technology.

(9) Analysis within the BRS indicates that HTP technology can be entirely consistent with sustainable agriculture and the growing of herbicide tolerant crops could contribute to more sustainable fa1rming systems.
